summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend engaged in a public row after Merson criticized Townsend's selection for the England team. Merson, a Sky Sports pundit, admitted he was wrong after Townsend scored a stunning equalizer for England against Italy. However, tensions rose again when Merson mocked Townsend's brief appearance for Tottenham against Burnley. Townsend initially hit back at Merson on Twitter after his goal, but the pair seemed to have made amends until Merson's latest comment.

Here is a concise summary of the passage: 

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward, Yoshinori Muto, according to the player's club president, Naoki Ogane. Muto, a Japan international with 11 caps, could become the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if he completes a move to Stamford Bridge. He would initially join Chelsea's partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, on loan for the upcoming season. Muto, a Keio University graduate with an economics degree, has had a successful goalscoring record at FC Tokyo and was named in the J-League's Best XI in his debut season. The potential transfer fee mentioned is £4 million, although Muto has expressed that he has not decided on his future yet. This development comes amid Chelsea's recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, but the two affairs are claimed to be unrelated.

Here is a concise summary of the passage: 

A large-scale study published in the medical journal Pediatrics has found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The Finnish research team compared weight, height, and antibiotic prescription records for over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and found a positive correlation between early antibiotic exposure and increased body mass, particularly in boys. The study suggests a potential link between antibiotics, appetite, and weight gain, mirroring their use in farming to promote weight gain in livestock. Lead author Dr. Antti Saari cautions that the widespread use of antibiotics may be contributing to the global obesity epidemic, emphasizing the need for cautious antibiotic use in infancy. Previous research has also linked early antibiotic exposure to higher risks of eczema and digestive issues. With concerns about antibiotic over-prescription and resistance growing, this study adds to the evidence that their use may have unintended consequences.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, an incident caught on camera by a tourist. The guard, who is anonymous, quickly stood up, but not before startling the crowd and causing a few gasps. This event occurred on a Thursday afternoon, with David Meadwell, a tourist, capturing the moment. The Ministry of Defense declined to comment, stating it was a young man falling while doing his job. This embarrassing moment occurred in front of hundreds of shocked tourists.

"Roots", the iconic miniseries from 1977 about African-American slavery, is being remade and simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History in 2016. LeVar Burton, the original Kunta Kinte, will co-executive produce. The new version aims to be more authentic and draw more from Alex Haley's novel. Producers aim to introduce the powerful story to a new generation.

Police are investigating claims by Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, who alleged that palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy at Clarence House in the 1970s. Mr. Lawler, now 64, described an incident from his first day of work in January 1978 when he was 27 years old. He was accosted by a group of men, groped, and almost had his trousers removed before managing to escape the room. Mr. Lawler immediately reported the incident to Clarence House and left his job, but his recent attempts to bring the matter to light again have faced delays. His complaints were initially ignored, but Scotland Yard has now been notified and a retired royal aide has been interviewed. The Palace has responded by stating their cooperation with any police investigations.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, revealed they are expecting a child in a creative way - through a rap video parody of the *Fresh Prince of Bel-Air* theme song. The video, which has gone viral with over 1.7 million views on YouTube, details their journey to pregnancy and includes a sonogram reveal. The couple shared that it was a way to announce the news to distant loved ones, and they were surprised by the positive response. This unique pregnancy announcement adds a modern twist to a classic '90s theme song.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The outfit, consisting of a jacket and full skirt, was one of over 150 items from the 1939 film offered by Heritage Auctions. The dress has faded over time but remains an iconic piece of cinema history. It was part of James Tumblin's private collection, which included over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia. Other top-selling items included a straw hat worn by Leigh and clothing worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after allegedly being dangled over the railing by his parents. The toddler slipped from his mother's grasp, falling 10 to 12 feet into the pit, but was quickly rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived. The boy sustained minor injuries and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. Zoo officials and witnesses stated that the cheetahs did not approach the child or his parents, possibly due to the commotion and screaming. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit has been temporarily closed.

A speed camera, non-functional for two years, has been angled directly at a residence in Birmingham, UK. Around 300 similar cameras were decommissioned in the West Midlands region in 2013 due to obsolete technology, replaced by mobile units and fixed motorway cameras. Mystery surrounds who repositioned the camera, but Birmingham City Council is aware and plans to send an engineer to potentially remove it. The camera is not intended to be included in a new pilot program for digital speed cameras.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medalist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt expressed his excitement, stating that he is fit and ready to run, and honored to represent Jamaica, a country with a renowned relay tradition. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association and JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle welcomed Bolt's participation, anticipating his sprint magic on the track.

"Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at FC Barcelona, showed their support for the club's basketball team by attending El Clásico against Real Madrid in the Euro League, which Barca narrowly won 85-80. Neymar, who plays for Brazil nationally, had a successful weekend, beating Chile 1-0 at the Emirates Stadium. Before the international break, Barcelona were leading La Liga after winning the football version of El Clásico, moving four points clear at the top. Neymar and his teammates will return to La Liga action on Sunday against Celta Vigo, chasing a treble of trophies. Neymar's sister, Rafaella, joined the players at the basketball, and Neymar also captained Brazil in their win, despite facing brutal challenges from Chilean players, including an apparent stamp from Gary Medel."

A rising number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East are attempting to reach Europe via Italy, with 8,480 rescued by the Italian Coast Guard between Friday and Monday. On Tuesday, concerns were raised by Save the Children that a boat carrying 550 migrants may have capsized, with only 145 survivors. The Italian Coast Guard has not confirmed this incident but has noted an increase in migrant crossings and rescues in recent months. Most migrants originate from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, transiting through Libya. The dangerous journey has already claimed the lives of at least 480 people this year due to harsh conditions and the negligence of smugglers.

Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to sign for Arsenal over Liverpool, with the forward having an instant impact at the Emirates Stadium. Sanchez has netted 19 goals so far this season and Wenger believes he is one of the best, adapting quickly to the Premier League with his efficiency, work rate, and fighting spirit. The Arsenal boss played down talk of a move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and praised Brendan Rodgers' management, acknowledging Liverpool's impressive goal-scoring record last season.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt cycling's hour record on June 7 at the London Olympic Velodrome. Wiggins, who is targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics, aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes at the Lee Valley VeloPark. The current record is held by Australian Rohan Dennis, who rode 52.491km in an hour. Wiggins' attempt will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with tickets going on sale for £29-£49.

Serena Williams described her difficult victory over Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as an "eye-opener" as she prepares for the clay court season. Williams struggled with Errani's style and the tough weather conditions, eventually winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3. Despite Williams' victory, the US lost to Italy 3-2 and was relegated to World Group II. Williams acknowledged that she needs to adjust her playing style and be prepared for longer rallies on clay courts. The French Open has been her least successful Grand Slam, but she is determined to improve her record this year. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez remains optimistic about the team's future, highlighting the depth of talent in the top 100 rankings.

River Plate are interested in re-signing their former striker, Radamel Falcao, who spent eight productive years at the club before moving to Porto in 2009. The Colombian forward has struggled on loan at Manchester United, scoring only four league goals, casting doubt on his future at the club. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the club's desire to bring Falcao back, calling it a dream, but acknowledged the complexities of such a move. Falcao, who found success at River Plate with 34 goals in 90 appearances, has stayed relevant by scoring regularly for Colombia, equaling their all-time goalscoring record.

Ella Henderson, the X Factor finalist known for her powerful vocals, has been chosen as the face of dry shampoo brand Batiste's 2015 "Ready For It" campaign. The campaign features images of the 19-year-old singer with various hairstyles, showcasing the product's versatility. This collaboration marks Henderson's first brand partnership and Batiste's first campaign with a platinum award-winning artist. The TV advertising campaign features Henderson's single "Mirror Man." Both Henderson and her management team at Crown Talent & Media Group expressed excitement about the partnership, with the brand being described as a natural fit for the singer.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was shot dead by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, are distressed by a billboard featuring the officer. They have called it 'disrespectful' and are asking for its removal, while the Kenosha Professional Police Association claims it is simply a message of gratitude to the community. The passage also details two recent incidents involving Torres, including the fatal shooting of Siler and the non-fatal shooting of Terry Knight, both of which are under investigation.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants from the group Jaish al Adal, who attacked from across the border with Pakistan. Three militants were also killed in the fighting. This is the latest in a series of incidents, with Iranian officials criticizing Pakistan for not doing enough to stop similar attacks. The Pakistani government has condemned the attack and promised to apprehend the assailants if they have crossed into Pakistan.

Here is a concise summary of the passage: 

The Japanese government's Defense Minister, Gen Nakatani, confirmed in a parliamentary session that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered a UFO believed to be of extraterrestrial origin. This statement was in response to a query from lawmaker Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler, who inquired about potential extraterrestrial threats and alien research. Inoki, a colorful figure in Japanese politics and entertainment, is known for his mixed martial arts career, humanitarian efforts, and diplomatic endeavors. The discussion highlights the lighthearted yet earnest approach taken by Japanese politicians when addressing the topic of extraterrestrial life and potential UFO sightings.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his left leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on broke at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China. Pai was standing on the toilet rim because he was concerned about its cleanliness but fell through when it collapsed. He was too embarrassed to call for help and instead contacted his companions. Authorities believed the incident was accidental, and a police spokesman reminded people to use toilets for their intended purpose.

A 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, Kevin Rebbie, was arrested on multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault and sexual abuse of children, after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. The camera contained 41 videos of the girl and others, including close-up images of genitalia, which Rebbie uploaded to his computer. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims over a three- to four-year period and purchasing the camera specifically to record the 15-year-old. He is alleged to have molested the girl while she was sleeping from the ages of nine to thirteen. Rebbie's bail is set at $500,000, and his preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest book, *Daughter and Salary Man*, features a unique take on father-daughter portraits. The images depict teenage girls standing stoically beside their fathers, who are leaping energetically into the air, often with expressive poses and faces. The concept aims to showcase the fun side of fathers, who usually have to maintain a serious demeanor. The title suggests a focus on the contrast between the daughters and their fathers' professional lives, with the fathers dressed sharply in suits. These photographs, set against various Japanese landmarks, have sparked curiosity and gained significant online interest.

Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England cricket set-up is a talking point ahead of the county championship season. Pietersen, who last played internationally during England's disastrous Ashes tour in Australia last year, looked deep in thought during a Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval. The batsman joked with photographers and teammates, including Chris Tremlett and Jade Dernbach, but also reflected on his possible sensational comeback, which has moved a step closer following the dismissal of England managing director Paul Downton, who controversially axed him in 2014. Pietersen has rejoined Surrey, starting with a match against Oxford MCCU on Sunday, aiming to force his way back into the Test team as England seek to regain the urn on home soil this summer.

Angelo Massone, the owner of Romanian football club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, has sacked head coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. The Brazilian former international defender had only been in the job since January, but a poor run of results, including a 2-0 defeat to FC Botosani, has seen him replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's ex-teammate at Monaco, believes Falcao regrets his loan move to Manchester United, despite his unhappiness in France. Falcao's struggles at United, attributed to a previous knee injury, have led to speculation that United will not permanentize the deal. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played Champions League football and been more content.

New Zealand Police are seeking information from the public to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. The incident occurred on Saturday, with the offender demanding cash from the owner's daughter and escaping with the till and approximately $1500. The owner, Christina Chen, expressed concern over the unusual nature of the robbery, as typically, such incidents involve the theft of cigarettes and other small items. Police are treating the case with seriousness and are urging anyone with relevant information to contact Crimestoppers or reach out online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for the second time in a month on charges of inappropriate relationships with underage pupils. The first arrest on March 19 involved a 15-year-old student, and she was released on bail. However, she was arrested again after another 15-year-old pupil accused her of sexual encounters on consecutive nights in January. Granado admitted to kissing one pupil and allowing him to touch her inappropriately, and detectives later discovered rumors of her involvement with the second pupil. She has been suspended from teaching and placed on administrative leave, with bail set at $50,000 for the latest charges.

A shocking video of a crocodile swimming in a Puerto Vallarta marina with a dead dog in its jaws has gained over half a million views. New Zealander Tim Weston, a tourist, captured the alarming sight and shared it online. The crocodile, a common sight in the area, attacked the dog belonging to a local bike shop owner. The incident has evoked horror and negative sentiments towards crocodiles from social media users. Puerto Vallarta's proximity to crocodile habitats, including a nearby sanctuary, means human and crocodile interactions are frequent.

Steve Bruce remains confident that Hull City will avoid relegation from the Premier League, despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton leaving them just two points clear of the drop zone. Bruce attributed Hull's struggles to long-term injuries to key players and expressed his belief that their remaining fixtures, which include difficult matches against top teams, will be crucial in ensuring their survival. Ronald Koeman, the Southampton manager, faced a separate challenge as he dealt with a dispute between players Sadio Mane and James Ward-Prowse over penalty-taking duties.

A primary school teacher, Ian Guffick, has been banned from teaching for at least two years after he asked pupils to change their SATs exam answers and altered some himself. This invalidated the entire school's SATs results for that year. An investigation by the local education authority and the Department for Education found that Guffick's conduct was unacceptable, and he was forced to leave his job. Guffick expressed remorse for his actions, but a panel concluded that his behavior could not be excused, despite not amounting to fraud or serious dishonesty.

Anders Lindegaard, the Danish goalkeeper for Manchester United, married Swedish-Albanian model Misse Beqiri in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year. The couple, who have a son together, recently enjoyed a day off together in the sun, with Lindegaard sharing a photo on Instagram. Despite his struggles for playing time at Manchester United, Lindegaard seems to be winning in his personal life with his beautiful wife and family.

The iconic Yankee Stadium sign, which lit up the Bronx from 1976 to 2008, failed to attract any buyers at a Sotheby's auction. The 13 glowing blue letters, each 10 feet tall and owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, were expected to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000. Jackson, who bought the sign on a whim, attended the auction and joked about the letters' size. Despite the sign's historical significance, the auction received no bids, highlighting the challenge of finding a new home for this piece of sports memorabilia. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s exceeded estimates, selling for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has spoken to players Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their off-field behavior and responsibilities as professional athletes. Despite the incident, neither player will be disciplined, and Rodgers wants to move on. He emphasized the need for players to understand the impact of their actions and how they are perceived by the public. With Steven Gerrard available after a suspension, Rodgers aims to guide Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management. He reflected on past losses and the importance of learning from them to improve and achieve future success.

Mesut Ozil, the Arsenal playmaker, took to Twitter to share a glimpse of his downtime, posting a photo of him relaxing with his dog upon returning to London. Ozil, a German star, contributed to Germany's 2-0 victory over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. He is now gearing up for Arsenal's Premier League clash with Liverpool. Ozil, signed from Real Madrid in 2013, has been in excellent form since recovering from injury, accumulating four assists and three goals. He expresses his comfort with the demands of English football, citing his preference for frequent matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has expressed his satisfaction with manager Luis Enrique, stating that the club has no plans to replace him. Enrique, who joined the club last summer on a two-year deal, has guided the team to a promising position just six games away from potentially winning the La Liga title. Despite speculation about his future, Bartomeu affirmed that Enrique has impressed them and has the full support of the club. The Barca president highlighted Enrique's dedication and hard work in preparing the team for crucial matches, and emphasized that the manager still has a contract until 2016. Enrique's side reinforced Bartomeu's statements with a convincing performance against Valencia, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi securing a comfortable victory.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool worth £100,000 per week until the summer of 2020. This comes as a boost for the club after their FA Cup semi-final loss. Henderson, who joined Liverpool in 2011, has been in excellent form this season with 13 assists and 7 goals. He is the third player to agree to an extension under Brendan Rodgers and is in contention to become club captain following Steven Gerrard's departure.

Filipe Luis has expressed his desire to remain at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite interest from his former club Atletico Madrid. Luis has struggled to establish himself as the first-choice left-back at Stamford Bridge, but he is focused on helping Chelsea win the Premier League title this season. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is demanding focus and concentration from his players as they enter a crucial period of nine challenging games to secure the league trophy.

Nathan Hughes has successfully appealed against his three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North with his knee, with the appeal panel concluding that no foul play took place. This decision comes despite initial criticism and condemnation of Hughes' actions, with many speaking up in his defense, including fellow players and club members. Hughes will not face any further sanctions and is free to return to action immediately, although he is unlikely to play again until April 26.

A stunning sunset over Seattle, captured by photographer Tim Durkan, was the result of wildfires in southeastern Siberia. The fires, started by farmers burning grass, grew out of control due to strong winds and destroyed dozens of villages. The smoke, carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific to the Pacific Northwest, caused intense red sunsets as smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors like green and blue, leaving reds and oranges unfiltered. This phenomenon is especially noticeable during sunrise and sunset when the light has more atmosphere to travel through. As the smoke dissipates, the sunsets will return to their normal hues.

A Missouri mother had her new car stolen from her driveway. The car was later returned by police, who had received a tip-off, with various aesthetic alterations, including red rims and detailing. Rather than being upset, she took to Facebook to humorously embrace the new look. She also acknowledged the man who found her car with a named smoothie in her restaurant.

Manchester City players stand to lose significant bonuses of £500,000 each if they fail to qualify for the Champions League. With recent losses, their participation in the tournament is at risk, and their fourth-place position is under threat from Liverpool. This situation reflects the club's strategy of offering incentivized contracts to stars like Sergio Aguero and David Silva to ensure compliance with financial fair play rules. The potential bonus loss for the entire squad amounts to approximately £12 million. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledged their poor performance in the last three months, and the club now faces challenges in signing top players like Paul Pogba.

Manchester United's Under 18s beat Manchester City 1-0 in the 'mini-derby', with a free-kick from Callum Gribbin being the difference between the two sides. The match, which took place at Altrincham's stadium, featured a large number of English and local players, and free entry for the approximately 1,000 fans in attendance. United's youth coach, Paul McGuinness, opted for a tactical setup similar to that used by the senior team this season. The game was an entertaining affair, with both sides showcasing their skills and commitment. The result leaves United in a strong position in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League, while City have now lost both of their end-of-season play-off series matches.

Joe Hart, England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised veteran Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after earning his 50th cap for England. Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, admired Buffon's longevity and performance at 37 years old, considering him an inspiration as he continues to learn and improve his own game. Hart described his pride in reaching 50 caps for England and expressed his desire to continue representing his country and achieving more milestones in the future.

Popular Mexican restaurant chain Chipotle is now offering food delivery in 67 cities through a partnership with the Postmates app. This move allows customers to have their burritos and other menu items delivered directly to their doors, with a nine per cent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. Chipotle is joining other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, who are also venturing into the $70 billion food delivery market. The passage also mentions celebrity endorsements for Chipotle, including presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio, who have been spotted at the restaurant.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have penned an emotional plea to remove the death penalty as an option for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was found guilty of 30 charges related to the bombings and subsequent events. Understanding the severity of the crimes, Bill and Denise Richard highlighted the toll the case has taken on their family, including the loss of their son and severe injuries to their daughter. They urge a swift conclusion to the case, favoring life imprisonment without parole over a potentially lengthy appeals process that would prolong their pain. The Richards' perspective, shared in the Boston Globe, reflects their desire to move forward and spare their remaining children from further trauma.

A mystery billionaire has reportedly spent £400million to convert a Boeing 747 into a luxurious private jet. The custom-built plane features bedrooms, multiple lounges, a dining room, a kitchen, and an office, accommodating the owner and several dozen guests. The jet's interior resembles a luxury hotel, with plush furnishings and decorations, offering an exclusive and glitzy flying experience far beyond commercial first-class.

SpaceX launched a two-stage Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed cargo ship called Dragon to the International Space Station (ISS) but failed to land the rocket stage on a floating barge. Despite the unsuccessful landing, founder Elon Musk remains committed to reusing rockets to reduce space access costs. The Dragon will deliver supplies, including an espresso maker, to the ISS, and return with science experiments and trash. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS, highlighting its pioneering role as the first private contractor to dock with the station.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. Presley collaborated with NBC's Today show to offer an Elvis-themed wedding contest for a lucky couple, including a reception, hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. The wedding will take place on April 23, with the winning couple announced the week prior. The chapel is located inside the Westgate Hotel (formerly Las Vegas Hilton), where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows. Presley, who ensured no impersonators would be involved, was closely involved in the chapel's design and feel. Couples must submit videos, photos, and explanations to be considered for the first wedding.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, believes they can catch Manchester City in the Premier League. Despite a challenging and lengthy season, with Henderson and Mignolet playing 47 games so far, Liverpool's win over Newcastle United has boosted their confidence. Henderson thinks they can put pressure on City, who are currently four points ahead. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen's goals secured the 2-0 victory, with Allen acknowledging the importance of the win after recent defeats. Allen also commented on a potential penalty for Newcastle, stating it looked like a strong claim but that these decisions can go either way.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home with a key victory over Napoli, moving them four points ahead of rivals Lazio in the race for Champions League places. The game was tight, with Roma taking the lead in the 25th minute through Miralem Pjanic, who also had a free kick narrowly miss. Napoli had chances, including a potential penalty, but Roma's goalkeeper, Morgan de Sanctis, denied them with several superb saves. The win was significant for Roma, ending a difficult period, while Napoli's winless streak extended to five games, affecting their Champions League aspirations. Security was high for the match, but no issues were reported.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played out a dull 0-0 draw at the Keepmoat Stadium, with a lack of notable action reflected in the mere 14 seconds of match action included in Doncaster's official highlights video.

A man has formed an unusual bond with his pet fish, a blood parrot cichlid, which he keeps in a tank. Despite fish being typically less tactile than cats or dogs, this fish enjoys physical interaction and being massaged by its owner. The fish and owner interact daily, with the fish displaying clear enjoyment and even seeking out this attention. The owner, Roland Giroux, has shared his unique bond through videos online, detailing how their relationship developed over time through hand-feeding and daily interaction.

Ben Stokes is a fiery character in the England cricket team who has faced both highs and lows in his career. He is known for his aggressive on-field behavior, such as clashing with Marlon Samuels during the second Test against the West Indies. However, Stokes has responded positively to coaching from England's coach, Peter Moores, who has helped him channel his aggression in the right way. Stokes is liked for his natural exuberance and desire to take on opponents, but he must be carefully managed to ensure his aggression does not get out of control. England wants to feature Stokes as much as possible to help him reach his full potential and grow into the international game.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier match against Belgium has sold out, with 33,000 tickets sold for the game at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12. With both teams level on points in Group B, and Wales aiming to qualify for their first major tournament since 1958, expectations are high for a significant game. The Football Association of Wales (FAW) confirmed the sell-out, noting the increased demand for tickets following Wales' impressive 3-0 victory over Israel. The Wales squad is believed to prefer the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium over the larger Millennium Stadium, which can hold 74,500 fans.

England's Under-17 football squad is announced for the upcoming UEFA European Championship in Bulgaria. The team, coached by John Peacock, features talented youngsters from Premier League clubs, including Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi. With a strong qualifying record, England aims to defend their title, starting with Group D matches against Italy, Holland, and Ireland.

Manchester City are interested in signing the highly-rated 14-year-old playmaker, Evangelos Patoulidis, from Anderlecht. Patoulidis is considered a top talent and has also attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona previously. City have initiated discussions with Anderlecht's chairman regarding a potential compensation package, as Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure promising young players for the club's future.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested and bailed in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican national working as a transgender escort in London. Miss Santillan's body was found in a flat in Fulham, with her death resulting from head and neck injuries. Scotland Yard is appealing for information from anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan before her death, and Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation, seeking to understand the motive for the crime.

A bereaved mother, Dawn, appeared on the Jeremy Kyle Show to confront her friend, Jamie, about stealing money intended for her baby's gravestone. She had suffered seven miscarriages and saved £207 towards a £500 gravestone. Jamie, a convicted burglar, lived with Dawn and her partner. Despite initial denials, a lie detector test revealed Jamie's guilt. A Facebook message from him declared his love for Dawn and confessed, blaming his girlfriend. Dawn expressed distress and betrayal, feeling devastated by the betrayal during her grieving process.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women and children, with a small number of ill and elderly, according to Peshmerga forces. The reason for the release is unknown, but Arab tribal leaders are said to have helped coordinate it. The freed Yazidis, a minority group targeted by ISIS, were received by Peshmerga and sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. This isn't the first time ISIS has released Yazidi captives, having previously displaced them from their homes in northern Iraq and subjected them to extreme cruelty, including slaughter and enslavement. The US and international allies have responded with airstrikes and humanitarian aid.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker, is having a remarkable season with a breakthrough performance earning him a spot on Roy Hodgson's England side. He is now being celebrated in an innovative animation that showcases his best goals and celebrations. The video, produced by Copa90, uses still photographs to animate Kane's highlights, including goals against Chelsea and Arsenal. Kane is nominated for both PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards, recognizing his incredible impact this season.

Jamie Carragher has publicly supported Brendan Rodgers, stating that he believes the Liverpool manager can turn the team's fortunes around and deliver trophies in the coming season. Carragher acknowledged the challenges faced by Rodgers and attributed the team's performance to the difficulty in integrating new players. Despite a likely finish outside the top four and a third consecutive trophy-less season, Carragher emphasized the importance of stability and highlighted Rodgers' ability to identify areas for improvement. The former Liverpool defender also praised Rodgers for his community work and his contribution to the club.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic toy gun, which fires sponge darts, confiscated by security at East Midlands Airport. His father, Phil Hayward, deemed the security checks "ludicrous" and "over-zealous," as the toy posed no threat. The airport defended its decision, citing security regulations that prohibit any items resembling prohibited items, including replica or model guns. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land to proceed with the project, which is considered an exciting development by county officials.

During a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, police discovered an elaborate grow house containing a large number of plants. A man in his late 40s was arrested in connection with the discovery.

A 28-year-old woman of German-Kurdish origin was severely injured in an assault in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, and had to undergo emergency surgery. The suspect, her 38-year-old ex-partner, who is also German-Kurdish, later turned himself in and is now in custody. Police are investigating the motive, and the area has been secured while they appeal for witnesses.

Research by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to request a pay rise, contrary to popular belief. The study, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, compared full-time and part-time workers of both genders and controlled for various factors. It concluded that men are 25% more likely to receive a pay increase when requesting one, indicating potential discrimination against women. Interestingly, women and men under 40 exhibited similar negotiation success rates, suggesting a potential shift in negotiating behavior across generations. The researchers suggested that younger women may continue this trend as they advance in their careers.

The Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site, but has been unable to find a suitable location due to factors such as ground conditions and size requirements. With existing cemeteries reaching capacity by 2021, the council continues to explore options, but acknowledges the challenge of limited suitable land in the area.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) is offering an augmented reality experience to enhance visitors' enjoyment. An app will provide online content, including videos and band interviews, accessible via phones and tablets by scanning signs and posters on-site. The festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22, features acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Skerryvore. The app will also allow global audiences to interact with HebCelt, access information, and purchase tickets remotely.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered a rare and severe pulmonary hemorrhage, with no underlying health issues detected. Trainer Oliver Sherwood mourned the loss of a remarkable horse. The incident has sparked discussions about the link between post-race ataxia and overheating, but authorities conclude that the hemorrhage was the primary cause of death.

Davina, formerly David Ayrton, has been found guilty of rape and is awaiting sentencing. The attack occurred in 2004 when Ayrton, then presenting as male, raped a 15-year-old girl while two others were asleep in a Portsmouth garage. The victim recalled the events clearly and said she had tried to stop the attack. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and identifies as female, disclosed the attack to a care home worker in 2014 and expressed suicidal thoughts last summer. Despite presenting as female, Ayrton will be held in a male prison, as decided by Judge Ian Pearson.

The Serbs lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, with a score of 6-4, 6-4. This defeat followed an unexpected loss for World Number One, Novak Djokovic, against Argentina's Juan Martin del Potro in the singles competition. Just a month prior, Djokovic suffered another surprise defeat at Wimbledon, losing to American Sam Querrey. However, he bounced back to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto ahead of the Olympic Games.

Over 20 chainsaw carvers will compete in this year's event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, including previous winners and entrants from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, and North America. Using only chainsaws, competitors will transform logs into intricate sculptures of animals and people, with the hope of winning the coveted Claymore Trophy.

Wales rugby player Webb is close to returning from a long-term foot injury, with a target return date of early February, in time for the Six Nations tournament. Webb has recommitted to his national team and Ospreys, turning down other offers, and is focused on getting back to international rugby.

Here is a concise summary of the passage: 

"US border agents interrupted a drug smuggling attempt on Tuesday morning, arresting two men near Sumas, Washington, accused of attempting to smuggle MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. One of the men, Nathan Hall, fled the scene and was later arrested in British Columbia, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody immediately. The total weight of the seized ecstasy was 58lb (26kg). Three additional people were arrested in connection with the smuggling attempt and are facing conspiracy and drug-related charges. The area where the incident occurred is known for drug and firearm smuggling activities."

In the last year, the NSPCC's Childline service counselled approximately 4,500 children who experienced online abuse and cyberbullying, a significant increase from 2,400 in 2011-12. The issue is widespread, with children as young as seven suffering torment and abuse, often feeling scared to attend school. Cyberbullying can follow children home, causing persistent persecution and misery. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, emphasizes the necessity for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and provide support. The report, released during Anti-Bullying Week, highlights the need for schools to address this issue seriously. Young people affected by cyberbullying often struggle to confide in their parents, and the advice given by fellow youths includes encouraging victims to seek help and stand up for themselves.

The passage details the recent developments in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, focusing on the response to a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction. The US abstained from voting, angering Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who believes the White House played a role in the resolution's passage. This led to a series of diplomatic actions by Israel, including recalling ambassadors and cutting aid. Despite initial plans to authorize new homes in settlements, the Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed the vote following a request from Netanyahu's office to avoid further tensions with the US ahead of Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the conflict. The resolution has been praised by Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas, who sees it as a step towards the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France.

Prince William has paid tribute to the Queen on her 90th birthday, praising her commitment to duty and service. He described her as a "guiding example" of a good monarch and highlighted her tolerance and dedication to others. The Duke of Cambridge also addressed criticisms of his own work ethic, stating that he takes his royal duties seriously but is trying to live a normal life for now. The Queen's birthday celebrations included the release of a new stamp featuring four generations of the Royal Family and various events in Windsor, with well-wishes from political leaders. The Queen and Prince Philip will also unveil The Queen's Walkway and light a beacon to mark the milestone.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in an EFL Cup match, with Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scoring quick goals before halftime. Cheltenham had chances but couldn't get past West Ham's defense, and the Premier League side controlled the match. The result ended League Two's participation in the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a motorcycle collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. The collision was caused by 46-year-old Andreas Werner, a visitor from Leipzig, who failed to spot Mr. McNicholl when turning his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to careless driving and was fined and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not wish for Werner to be jailed, understanding the lapse in judgement, and Werner expressed remorse for the tragic accident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old man from London, attempted to return to the UK last year after joining a group of British jihadists in Syria. While his specific activities in Syria remain unknown, he was a prominent online presence among Syrian fighters and is considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists. He was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with the Islamic State, and played a role in creating propaganda videos and appeals for donations. Despite attempts to conceal his return and fake his death, he was arrested upon his arrival in Dover and is now facing life imprisonment. The passage also highlights the involvement of the British security service MI5 and the Metropolitan Police's counter-terrorism command in addressing the threat posed by returning jihadists.

Kayden Jackson, 22, has signed for Barnsley ahead of their League One play-off final. Jackson scored four goals in 36 games for Wrexham last season and will add pace and attacking threat to Barnsley's lineup, according to caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom.

National Trust volunteers are clearing detergent bottles that have washed up at Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves in Cornwall. The bottles are believed to have come from a container that went overboard from the MV Blue Ocean during stormy weather in May near Land's End. While the Cornwall Wildlife Trust expresses concern over the potential impact on marine life, most bottles remain sealed and full. The public is advised to keep a safe distance and not attempt to recover any bottles.

"A road crash occurred on the A9 in Caithness, Scotland, resulting in one fatality and multiple minor injuries. The incident took place north of Berriedale around 2 p.m., leading to a road closure and diversions via the A897. Police Scotland is investigating the incident further."

Dorian Dervite, 28, has signed a new contract with Bolton after helping them secure promotion to the Championship. The French centre-back made 14 appearances last season as Bolton finished second in League One. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contribution, calling him "a bit of a forgotten man" who made a significant impact towards the end of the campaign. Dervite is the fourth player to sign a new deal with the club, following David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour, the two biggest opposition parties, have a history of forming alliances to inflict defeats on the government, including on Brexit-related issues. However, their cooperation ended when the Lib Dems insisted on amendments concerning EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, while Labour deferred to the Commons. This led to accusations of "grandstanding" and providing "false hope" from both sides. Despite predictions of "residual tensions," the parties may still work together on issues of agreement.

In the upcoming election, defence policy has taken a backseat in most political parties' campaigns, despite growing global instability and threats. The UK's defence budget has faced significant cuts, resulting in reductions to the Army, Navy, and Air Force personnel and equipment. The absence of a commitment to NATO's 2% GDP spending target has raised concerns about the country's ability to maintain its military capabilities and credibility, particularly with key allies like the US. With the possibility of further cuts on the horizon, political parties are divided over the future of defence spending, including the renewal of Britain's nuclear deterrent programme, Trident.

Barcelona have made a voluntary tax payment of £11.2m relating to the signing of Neymar but deny any wrongdoing. The club paid £48.6m for the player, but it is alleged that the actual cost was far greater when taking into account additional contracts. The total cost of Neymar to the club is estimated to be £106.8m when including fees, wages, and this latest tax payment. The transfer is under investigation, and a Spanish judge has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue inquiries. Barcelona's statement insists they believe the original tax payment was correct but made the additional payment to protect the club's reputation. It remains unclear if the case will be dropped following this payment.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old passenger in a van, sadly passed away in a tragic car collision with a car driving the wrong way on the motorway. The driver of the car, Albert Kenneth Newman, was also killed in the incident. Mr. Luciw's family has called for mandatory regular driving tests for retired individuals, believing that older drivers may have slower reactions and pose a risk on the road. They suggest that a formal testing process, similar to a medical examination, could help avoid such tragic accidents in the future. Age UK, however, emphasizes the importance of mobility for older individuals and asserts that evidence does not support the notion that older drivers are more prone to causing serious accidents. The DVLA, the licensing agency, shares a similar stance and has no plans to implement age-based restrictions. This incident highlights the ongoing debate between road safety and the independence of elderly drivers.

"Despite concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants and calls for a ban, the Scottish government is implementing the recommendations of an independent review. The review, which faced strong opposition and protests from campaigners and patients, concluded that the procedure should not be routinely offered for pelvic organ prolapse and that patients should be informed of alternative treatments and potential side effects. Over 20,000 Scottish women have received mesh or tape implants in the last two decades, with some experiencing debilitating complications. As a result, legal action is being taken by over 400 women."

Laura Muir, 23, broke the previous 5K record set by Liz McColgan 25 years prior, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. Initially, there were questions about the legitimacy of the record due to the lack of competitors in the race and the absence of drug testing. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time would be classified as official, as there is no requirement for drug testing when setting a British record. McColgan praised Muir's performance and expressed her belief that Muir has the potential to win world medals and improve her 5K time further. The passage also mentions Muir's success in breaking the British 1500m record and her Olympic final appearance at Rio 2016.

Jung wins gold, Nicolas silver, and Dutton bronze in an Olympic equestrian event. GB's William Fox-Pitt finishes 12th, despite a recent fall and induced coma. Fox-Pitt led after the dressage phase but dropped to 21st after cross-country. Ireland's Jonty Evans finishes ninth.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini in four sets to reach the fourth round of Wimbledon, where he will face Benoit Paire. Murray dropped the second set but avoided a deciding fifth set by winning five games in a row to take the match. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also progressed to the second week for the first time with a straight-sets victory over Maria Sakkari. Murray acknowledged that the match was tense and that the fading light affected his thinking, but he was pleased to avoid a potential interruption for the roof to be closed. He acknowledged his opponent's talent and temperament, and the impact of Fognini's ankle injury. Murray saved set points in the fourth set and fought back to seal the victory, despite not feeling at his best. He is optimistic about the next round and the opportunity for a deep run in the tournament.

Paramedics and police attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar, Dungiven, on October 6, 2014. Till receipts indicated alcohol was served after licensing hours. The court ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. The defense admitted non-adherence to licensing laws. The judge criticized O'Neill's record and imposed fines of £3,000 and £1,000, respectively.

Mike Nesbitt, ending his speech for the Ulster Unionists, stated that the election should be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. However, his comments shifted the focus onto his party, with senior colleague Danny Kennedy publicly disagreeing. Nesbitt stood by his statements, encouraging voters to support any candidate promoting positive change. He expressed a preference for partnering with the SDLP over Sinn Féin and highlighted his support in unionist areas. The manifesto, 'Real Partnership', includes tackling waiting lists, boosting PSNI numbers, supporting the LGBT community, and addressing Brexit impacts. The election, according to Nesbitt, is about incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption, hoping this message resonates more than the controversy over his transfer remarks.

The passage describes a motion put forward by Justice Minister Claire Sugden, which aims to provide automatic pardons for gay and bisexual men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences in Northern Ireland. This move will align with the recent proposals in England and Wales, dubbed "Turing's Law", which offer posthumous pardons and allow living men to apply for pardons as well. The motion, soon to be considered by the assembly, emphasizes equal treatment and aims to rectify past injustices within the criminal justice system.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old runner from Kinross, Scotland, broke the Scottish record in the 1500m race, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This achievement also placed her second on the British all-time list. Muir expressed her pleasure with her performance, especially as it was her first race of the season at this distance. She attributed her success to her effective training regimen, which she fits around her veterinary studies. Muir now sets her sights on securing an Olympic spot for Great Britain in Rio.
The passage provides a collection of images from Scotland's top 26 beaches, specifically highlighting those with the highest water quality standards.

Richard Horwell QC suggests that the Russian state was likely behind the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko with polonium-210 in London, resulting in his death. While the suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, had no personal motive, the Russian state had reasons to wish Litvinenko harm. Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his accusations against the FSB could have been seen as treachery, providing a motive for the Russian state's involvement. The suspects left a trail of scientific evidence with no credible explanation, and extradition attempts have failed. The risk of polonium radiation exposure to the London public remains unknown.

Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as the new captain of Australia's Test cricket team. He already leads the one-day side and will also captain the Twenty20 team while Aaron Finch is injured. Smith's vice-captain is David Warner, who has been chosen despite past disciplinary issues, reflecting his newfound maturity. This decision comes after Michael Clarke, 34, retired following Australia's defeat to England in the Ashes. Smith has previously captained the Test side when Clarke was injured and has an impressive playing record, having played 32 Tests and scored nearly 3,000 runs. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and believes he is the right choice to fill Clarke's shoes.

Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron has expressed his passion for LGBT+ rights and his commitment to defending equal marriage laws, despite refusing to answer questions about his personal beliefs on homosexual sin. He has also highlighted his desire to extend marital rights for transgender individuals and ensure equal access to marriage for all, addressing the current spousal veto law. Mr. Farron justified his vote against the Equality Bill in 2007 by citing concerns over individual liberty protections, reaffirming his support for equality and equal access under the law regardless of sexuality.

Accord Healthcare is taking over a drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, previously owned by Sanofi, which closed in 2015 resulting in a loss of 450 jobs. Accord's investment is expected to have a positive impact on the area, bringing highly skilled jobs and long-term investment to Newcastle, boosting the local economy and strengthening the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sector.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving their senior roles at the local council. Their departures have raised questions about the council's ability to retain senior staff, with opposition leader Stephen Flynn predicting more exits. Mr. Ellis served as interim director of corporate governance and acted as deputy chief executive. Ms. Monaghan and Mr. Sutherland headed the council's human resources and customer services. Despite the concerns, council chief executive Angela Scott recognized the trio's professionalism.

Martin has decided to step away from road racing on Hondas for the remainder of the year following a challenging TT filled with crashes and mechanical issues. He clarifies his decision is not a quit from racing altogether but a shift towards classic and unique races.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a landslide victory in Nigeria's gubernatorial elections, winning 19 of 28 states, dealing a significant blow to the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). This marks the PDP's worst defeat since 1999 and follows their loss in the presidential poll last month. The APC's success extends to key northern states and Nigeria's commercial hub, Lagos, while the PDP retained power primarily in the south-east and oil-rich regions. Violence and ethnic tensions marred parts of the election process, yet overall, the elections indicated a maturing democracy. The PDP's decline is attributed to corruption allegations, defections, and the party's inability to address the Islamist-led insurgency. The APC's historic win highlights a shift in power dynamics, relegating the PDP to a regional party, and presenting challenges for the incoming administration regarding oil revenue and militant groups.

US-based environmental group Mighty accuses agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of turning a blind eye to unsustainable and environmentally damaging practices in the palm oil industry, particularly in Indonesia and Gabon. Olam denies the allegations, emphasizing its strict sourcing policy against burning, deforestation, and peat. The controversy highlights the challenges faced by the palm oil industry, which is often accused of unfair labor practices and environmental degradation. Mighty's report further implicates Singapore's state fund, Temasek, in the annual haze affecting Southeast Asian countries, as it is a majority stakeholder in Olam. Temasek dismisses the claims, stating it does not direct the operations of its portfolio companies. The palm oil industry's impact on the environment and the debate between green groups and executives are discussed, along with the need for government intervention and the complexity of enforcing environmental standards.

As of August 27, 2016, a new law permits dogs to dine with their owners outdoors at restaurants. This unique development has led to the creation of "puppy platters," specially designed menus, and dining options for our furry friends.

Derby County striker David Nugent could return from a groin injury, while midfielder Jacob Butterfield hopes for a recall after scoring as a substitute in the previous game. Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury, having only recently returned and featuring from the bench in recent games.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube after Google, which owns the video-sharing website, launched a Pakistan-specific version. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) has confirmed that internet service providers have been directed to open access to YouTube. This move has been welcomed by many young Pakistanis, while activists are calling for transparency in the deal between Google and the government. According to Pakistan's ministry of information technology, Google has provided a process for the PTA to request the blocking of offensive material directly from Google, which will then restrict access for users in Pakistan. However, a YouTube spokeswoman stated that government requests for content removal would be considered but not automatically granted, and that the process would be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report. The ban on YouTube was originally imposed by Pakistan's Supreme Court in 2012 due to the hosting of blasphemous content, which sparked widespread protests and led to multiple deaths.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is under pressure to step down from the 2016 FIFA presidential elections due to sharing Swiss-Italian nationality with one of the candidates, Gianni Infantino. Musa Bility, the LFA boss, has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. Scala and another committee member, Claudio Sulser, previously stepped aside during the 2015 elections between Swiss Sepp Blatter and Prince Ali of Jordan to avoid any potential conflict of interest based on nationality. However, Scala's spokesman, Andreas Bantel, argues that there is no conflict of interest in the current situation as there is no incumbent President among the five candidates. The election to replace long-standing President Blatter will take place in 18 days, with 209 FIFA members voting at the organization's headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland.

Two men, Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56), were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments on Spar Road, where they worked in a paint-spraying area. The explosion was likely caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, resulting in a fireball. The incident is being investigated by police and the Health and Safety Executive, with forensic inquiries and witness statements contributing to a better understanding of the tragedy.

Tunisia has avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints lodged during the 2015 Nations Cup, held in Equatorial Guinea. Morocco, briefly banned by Caf for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, will also compete in 2017 after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned their ban. Both nations' football associations express optimism about the future, with Tunisian differences considered resolved. Tunisia seeks a record 13th straight Nations Cup appearance and their first triumph since 2004.

"Following a mass fracas in the final minutes of the game, Manchester City received the majority of the blame and punishments for their part in the incident. Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off and subsequently banned for four and three matches, respectively. Pep Guardiola apologised for his team's actions. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will face no further punishment."

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan in the second Test, leveling the four-match series. Joe Root shone, scoring a double century and an unbeaten seventy, earning him the 'man of the match' award. Root's performance, along with centuries from Alastair Cook and a disciplined team effort, led to England's second-biggest win over Pakistan. Pakistan's batting struggles and poor shot selection were noted, with only two players crossing fifty in the series thus far. The series is predicted to remain tightly contested, despite England's comprehensive win in the second Test.

Warren Gatland, head coach of the British and Irish Lions, has appointed Rob Howley as interim coach while he is in New Zealand. Forwards coach, McBryde, will take on the role of head coach for Wales' summer tour, his third time in this position. The Welsh Rugby Union will provide assistant coaches to support McBryde. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes that the experience of Welsh coaches on the Lions tour will benefit the development of coaches and players, providing a valuable opportunity for growth.

Charlie Austin's early penalty put Southampton in control, but Hull City came from behind to secure a vital win, ending a six-game losing streak. Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson scored in quick succession midway through the second half to turn the game around, and despite late pressure, the Saints couldn't find an equaliser. Hull's win moves them off the foot of the table, while Southampton will look to bounce back after a busy schedule.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at around 2:15 p.m. BST. The road was closed in both directions between Woodhall Spa and Horncastle, with police appealing for witnesses to come forward.

President Ivanov has cancelled an investigation into allegations of abuse of power in Macedonia, a decision that has been criticized by both the opposition and EU officials. The allegations stem from covert recordings released in 2015 by opposition leader Zoran Zaev, which appear to reveal government corruption and abuse of power. Protests have broken out, and EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn has stated that Macedonia's EU membership ambitions are now at risk.

Swansea are seeking a new manager after sacking Bob Bradley, with Paul Clement their top target. The club fears that relegation may be difficult to bounce back from, having witnessed the struggles of similar clubs. Swansea's rise from near-bankruptcy to the Premier League is well-documented, and they are keen to maintain their top-flight status. Interim manager Alan Curtis, a long-serving member of the club, believes Swansea has lost their way since Michael Laudrup's departure, and hopes to remind players of the club's history and the importance of avoiding relegation.

Leyton Orient defeat Dagenham & Redbridge 3-2, relegating them from League One and ending their time in the Football League. Orient's victory keeps their play-off hopes alive, while Dagenham, who conceded two early goals, will need to promote themselves back up from the National League next season under manager John Still.

Steven Gerrard, former Liverpool captain, is returning to the club as a youth coach in February, his first job since retiring as a player. Gerrard has expressed his ambition to become a manager in the future, and is currently working on obtaining his UEFA A coaching license. His appointment has been well-received by Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp, who praised Gerrard's playing experience and potential as a future manager. Gerrard had a successful 19-year playing career, winning numerous trophies with Liverpool before leaving in 2015 to join LA Galaxy.

"McManus' early goal and Forbes' deflected strike gave Morton a strong start, with a pre-half-time goal from McAusland keeping Alloa in the game. However, McManus' second goal and a late strike by Johnstone secured a comfortable victory for Morton."

Ofsted has uncovered evidence of children being educated in unsanitary and hazardous environments in Birmingham, leading to the closure of three unregistered institutions suspected of operating as illegal schools. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, expressed concern that these cases might represent the tip of the iceberg and emphasized the possibility of children being abused or radicalized in such settings. In response, the government is taking action by providing funding for inspectors to investigate, consulting on plans for increased regulation, and preparing prosecutions against unregistered schools. The issue is not limited to any specific religious group, and the regulations will apply across the board to ensure the safety and well-being of children receiving education.

Lilliard Gin is a small-batch craft gin produced in the Scottish Borders, operated by lead distiller Kate Macinnes. It is based at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh, reflecting the rich local flavor palette of the Teviot valley. The distillery is named after a legendary figure, Lilliard, heroine of the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The gin aims to showcase the region's wild botanicals and is expected to contribute to the area's reputation for distilling excellence.

"Gary Green, 51, from Wakefield, UK, was jailed for 16 months after he reversed a tractor and fatally hit Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, in August 2013. Green was intoxicated, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer prior to the incident, and was found to be more than twice over the legal driving limit. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, shared the devastating impact on their close-knit family, pleading that drunk driving is never acceptable. The case was prosecuted under health and safety laws as it occurred on private land, and the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) inspectors described Green's behavior as reckless."

Luis Suarez has had his appeal against a four-month ban for biting partially upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). While he remains banned from playing in competitive matches, he is now allowed to train and play in friendlies for club and country. The striker, who joined Barcelona from Liverpool last month, will make his debut for the Spanish club in El Clasico against Real Madrid on 26 October.

On March 18, 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a unique race, beating competitors from Lithuania and others. The event, which doesn't require participants to be married, involves carrying your partner through a 380-meter obstacle course, including haystack hurdles and a steep slope. Richard and Anna will now represent their country at the World Championships in Finland in July 2014.

UK Transport Minister Stephen Hammond reassures Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that there will be no job losses at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) despite the upcoming abolition of paper car tax discs. In a letter, Mr. Hammond explains that while job roles may change and evolve with the introduction of an electronic tax system and direct debit payments, any reductions in staff will be managed through redeployment, not redundancies. Mr. Hedges expresses his satisfaction with the minister's response, acknowledging the benefits of the new system for citizens while also recognizing the reduced job opportunities at the DVLA.

The passage discusses the tension between Hungary and the European Union (EU) over Hungary's recent passage of controversial laws. The laws in question pertain to tight controls on asylum seekers, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and higher education. The EU, along with human rights groups and Hungarian citizens, have criticized these laws and called for their withdrawal. However, Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has refused to back down, arguing that these laws are within their domestic jurisdiction. Hungary has the support of Poland, which has vowed to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The situation has raised questions about the compatibility of Hungary's actions with EU law and the potential impact on the country's membership and voting rights in the EU.

Emma Watson will star as Belle in a new Beauty and the Beast film, alongside Kevin Kline as her father, Maurice. The film also features Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Bill Condon is directing the movie, which will be released on March 17, 2017, in the US.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and author, passed away from cancer. He was known for his distinctive writing style, controversial opinions, and dictating his articles due to dyslexia. Despite criticism over his provocative statements, he was highly regarded in the industry, with colleagues and competitors alike paying tribute to his talent and unique voice. His career spanned art reviews in the 1980s to his long-standing role at the *Sunday Times*, and he left a lasting impact on British journalism.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, was allegedly attacked on stage in Ulan Bator while wearing a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika. The swastika is a symbol with a long history in Mongolia, predating its association with Nazis, and is often used by Mr. Sukhbaatar, who is known for his patriotic performances. The rapper was beaten and kicked, resulting in a coma, with the alleged attacker being a Russian official who has not been arrested despite an ongoing investigation. The Russian embassy has denied the accuracy of local press reports, and the rapper's lawyer, father, and band member have refuted claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during his performance. This incident has sparked discussions about the swastika's varying cultural meanings and the sensitive history surrounding World War II.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a protest against airport expansion on Monday. The protesters have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area. They will appear in court on August 19. The Metropolitan Police have stated that airport security will be reviewed.

Nick Selman's impressive century (101 off 144 balls) dominated Glamorgan's innings, despite regular wickets falling due to the effective seam bowling of Matt Taylor and Craig Miles. Selman's performance marked a return to form after a string of low scores. Gloucestershire's bowlers kept the game evenly balanced by the end of the day, with Glamorgan's Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten ensuring a consolation bonus point. The game is set to be a challenging battle for both sides, with Gloucestershire's batsmen facing a tough task against Glamorgan's strong bowling attack.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after engaging in online conversations with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Hughes made threats on two separate late-night occasions while intoxicated, admitting to planning a false report of a crime to lure police officers and then shoot them. With a previous firearm conviction, Hughes was remanded in custody and will be sentenced for his admitted charges next week. His legal team argued that he had no intention of acting on his threats.

Yorkshire suffered a disappointing loss to Surrey in their bid to reach the Lord's final for the first time since 2002. Despite a strong start, dropping Ben Foakes proved costly as he and Davies shared a crucial stand of 130. Surrey's timely wickets, including a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, derailed Yorkshire's run-chase. Tim Bresnan's valiant effort wasn't enough, and they fell short by 19 runs. Surrey's skipper Gareth Batty praised the team's unity, while Yorkshire's captain Alex Lees acknowledged their shortcomings in crucial moments.

A converted trawler, measuring 56ft (17.1m) radioed for help as it was taking on water about 6 miles (10 km) off the coast. The RNLI lifeboat team provided a pump and towed the vessel to safety in Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games to focus on her veterinary medicine studies and exams. Despite her absence from the team, Muir is optimistic about her future in athletics, aiming for at least two more Olympics. She is also considering the World Indoor Championships in March. Muir recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, achieving a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds.

- Liverpool are far from mounting a title challenge this season, and will need to improve significantly just to finish in the top four.
- The loss of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's injury have seen a sharp decline in goals scored, and manager Brendan Rodgers' signings have failed to fill the gap.

A new £45m educational facility in Kilmarnock will be named after renowned writer William McIlvanney. The campus will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. McIlvanney, born and educated in Kilmarnock, was an influential novelist, poet, journalist, and broadcaster. He contributed greatly to Scotland's cultural and sporting life and is known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir". The campus aims to honour his legacy and his passion for providing good education to young people.
