Del Potro, a former US Open champion, defeated Swiss player Wawrinka in a thrilling match to progress to the next round of Wimbledon. The Argentine, who has endured an injury-plagued few years, came back from losing the first set to win 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3. In other results, Nick Kyrgios and Feliciano Lopez progressed through to set up a third-round match, while Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also won.

Tunisia has avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints lodged during the 2015 Nations Cup, particularly regarding a controversial penalty decision in their quarter-final exit. Morocco, who were banned for withdrawing as hosts of the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, have also been reinstated and will participate in the 2017 qualifiers. Both nations' football associations express optimism about the future, with Tunisian official Maher Snoussi stating their differences with Caf have been resolved. Tunisia aims to extend their record streak of Nations Cup appearances, while Morocco seeks a successful return to the competition.

McLaren's Formula 1 team, despite their illustrious history and successful partnerships with Honda and Mercedes, are currently experiencing a slump in performance. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998, and they have since been plagued by scandals, technical issues, and a decline in results. However, team principal Ron Dennis remains confident that McLaren will bounce back and break Mercedes' hegemony in F1. The team's current drivers include two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton, and they are working to arrest the slide and return to their former glory.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics and police were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven, following a sudden death. Till receipts indicated that alcohol was served past licensing hours, with the latest sale at 04:49 BST. As a result, the court ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. The defense solicitor admitted that licensing laws were not followed, and the judge expressed concern over the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence for Ms. O'Neill's "appalling record." Fines of £3,000 and £1,000 were given to Ms. O'Neill and Mr. Thomas, respectively.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for the most three-pointers in a single season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry entered the game four three-pointers short of his previous record of 272 and made eight during the game. The Warriors came back from a 13-point deficit with the help of Curry and Klay Thompson, who added nine assists and 26 points, respectively. The Portland Trail Blazers' LaMarcus Aldridge and Damian Lillard performed well, but it wasn't enough to secure a win. In other NBA news, the Chicago Bulls made a stunning comeback against the Miami Heat, outscoring them 57-27 in the second half. Pau Gasol's double-double of 16 points and 15 rebounds, along with contributions from Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson, led the Bulls to victory. Miami's Dwyane Wade had a poor shooting night, and the Heat suffered a blow to their playoff hopes.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised by YouTube star and free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen, who disguised himself as a competition winner. Van Velzen impressed the players with his skills, and later revealed his true identity as a YouTube sensation known for his free-kick videos. The players, especially Balotelli, were fooled and entertained by Van Velzen's performance.

Women who carry the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of dying from breast cancer by undergoing an oophorectomy (ovary removal). A study found that this procedure reduced the risk of death by over 60% for BRCA1 carriers, specifically when performed within two years of a breast cancer diagnosis. The procedure's protective effect was observed immediately and lasted for 15 years. The study analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with mutated BRCA genes, with a 20-year survival rate of 77.4%. Oophorectomy was particularly beneficial for BRCA1 carriers with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. The procedure did not show the same benefits for those with the BRCA2 mutation. Angelina Jolie's decision to undergo this procedure has brought awareness to the impact of genetic factors on cancer risk and treatment options.

A North Carolina couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by Amtrak Train No. 80, headed from Charlotte to New York City, on Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, though there was a delay of about three hours before the train continued its journey. The couple may have been living in a homeless camp, according to a man who knew them.

Carlos Toro, 66, an informant who worked for the DEA for 27 years, is facing deportation from the United States. Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, fled Colombia in the 1980s and provided information to the DEA, becoming one of their most valuable assets. He helped carry out undercover stings and provided information that led to the prosecution of several high-profile figures, including Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite being promised US citizenship, Toro has not received it and is now facing an uncertain future. He fears for his life if he is deported to Colombia and is struggling to obtain legal documentation to remain in the US, with his temporary visa having expired.

The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating Vox Populi Registry Ltd., a Canadian company that is using the new '.sucks' domain name to charge celebrities and companies high prices to protect their reputations. Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift are among those who have paid to remove their names from these domains. ICANN is working with Canadian and US regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal and if the company has violated its contract. The company recommends reselling the domains for $2,499 a year, with most being sold by resellers for around $2,000 annually.

The body of a baby boy, who was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating in a village pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, in 1988, has finally been identified as that of a baby boy named Peter. The baby's mother, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she explained that the baby was stillborn and that she had concealed the pregnancy. The baby has now been reburied with a new headstone, and the police have ruled out any foul play.

A taxi driver has been ordered to pay compensation to a former passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who sustained severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving car. Mr Hicks, who was 23 at the time, had an argument with the driver, Michael Young, who mistakenly believed Mr Hicks would not pay the fare and decided to teach him a lesson by driving him back to the taxi rank. As a result, Mr Hicks jumped out of the vehicle, suffering devastating injuries and now requires 24-hour care. The High Court ruled that Mr Young had unlawfully imprisoned Mr Hicks and ordered compensation, with the exact amount yet to be decided but estimated to be in the hundreds of thousands.

Severe weather, including tornadoes, hail, and flooding, impacted multiple states across the Midwest on Wednesday night and Thursday. Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, with additional storms moving through the state. The National Weather Service also received indications of a potential tornado in Potosi, Missouri, with reports of wind damage and flooding in the area. Social media users in Missouri shared photos and videos of the storm's impact, including downed trees, roof damage, and flooded streets. Chad Myers, a CNN severe weather expert, warned of the deadly nature of nighttime tornadoes. The severe weather system is expected to continue affecting the Midwest, the Mississippi River Valley, the Tennessee River Valley, and the southern Great Lakes region on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to face each other in a middleweight clash in New Jersey on Saturday. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth straight win since his loss to Vitor Belfort two years ago and is confident about his chances, stating that he needs "a big set of balls" and that he has to "be the bull" to dominate Machida. He acknowledges Machida's elusiveness and unique style but believes he has the skills to force Machida to fight his fight. Rockhold also respects Machida's longevity and status in the sport but is determined to showcase his own style and extend his winning streak. Meanwhile, Machida is equally confident, believing that his strategy and technique can stop Rockhold and earn him a title shot.

A plane made an emergency landing without deploying its landing gear, skidding along the runway on its belly. Shocking footage, captured in Fort Pierce, Florida, shows the light aircraft approaching the Aero Acres Residential Airpark. Despite appearing to descend normally, the plane touches down without its landing gear, causing damage to its propellers and creating a distinctive, unforgettable sound. In a quick reaction, the pilot re-engages the engines and takes off again. The video maker expresses surprise that the plane's engines remained intact and functional despite the impact. The pilot, later identified as 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, managed to fly approximately 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The incident, known as a "gear-up landing" or "belly landing," was likely due to human error or a mechanical fault, and is under investigation by the FAA.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed his disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season, but pledged his support for the player until the end of the current campaign. The club has struggled in their Premier League defense and Sportsmail revealed that they are open to offers for Toure as they plan to revamp their aging squad. Toure, with two years left on a high-value contract, is determined to stay, but Pellegrini acknowledged his underperformance. City's poor form has also raised questions about Pellegrini's future, but goalkeeper Joe Hart defended the manager, stating that the players let him down at times. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warned left-back Aaron Cresswell, who is attracting interest from City and Chelsea, to learn from the experiences of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who had limited playing time during their stints at the club.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive, will remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped due to a legal technicality. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was sentenced to seven years in prison by an Italian court in 1999 for his involvement with the Cosa Nostra. He fought extradition for a year and a half but was told he must return to Italy. However, it has now emerged that his case expired in October 2023, and his European Arrest Warrant will be withdrawn. While his conviction still stands, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the sentence time has passed. Rancadore's solicitor expressed delight that her client would now be able to live peacefully in England with his family.

AP McCoy is set to ride Mr Mole in his last Grade One race at Sandown on Saturday. Mr Mole is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in a field of seven runners, alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. Mr Mole is trained by Paul Nicholls, and the ride will be a notable one for McCoy as it was after winning on this horse at Newbury in February that he first announced his intention to retire.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and murdered by Jerome Sidney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after her disappearance, and Ritter has recently seen the crime scene photos, describing her daughter's injuries and expressing her desire for revenge. Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years, with a different suspect initially charged before being cleared due to lack of evidence.

Rory McIlroy is determined to win the Masters and complete a career grand slam. Despite only having one top-10 finish in six attempts, he believes it is "unthinkable" that he won't win at Augusta at some point in his career. McIlroy sees it as a "career-long goal" to join the exclusive list of players who have won all four major titles. He views the course as a "sanctuary" and is eager to emulate the greats of the game. The 25-year-old believes he can win multiple times at Augusta and sees the 2011 Masters, where he collapsed in the final round, as a crucial learning experience that contributed to his subsequent major victories.

This week's trending stories included a rare quadruple rainbow captured in New York, an unusual funeral tradition in rural China, and RDJ's uncomfortable interview with a UK channel. Social media trends focused on lip plumping and the #KylieJennerChallenge. Other notable mentions were Alice Barker's time travel experience, a controversial prom proposal, and casting choices for 'Beauty and the Beast'. The week also saw unique pregnancy announcements, and a heartwarming military dad photobomb.

Hundreds of children in England were hospitalized last year due to brain damage caused by prenatal alcohol exposure, known as Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS). The official number was 272, but experts warn that the true count may be much higher. Research suggests that at least 7,500 babies are born each year in the UK with learning, behavioral, and physical difficulties due to FAS. FAS can lead to permanent problems, and affected children may require lifelong assistance. The issue is under-diagnosed, and there are calls for pregnant women to be advised to abstain from alcohol entirely.

An attempted robbery at a store in County Durham was foiled when the owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled the axe-wielding robber to the ground, while his wife, Sam, hit the robber with a baseball bat, causing him to drop his weapon. The robber, Shaun Andrew McKerry, was arrested and later jailed for six years for attempted robbery. McKerry had a history of offending, dating back to his juvenile years, and had earned the nicknames "Boomerang Boy" and "Homing Pigeon Boy" due to his frequent returns home after committing crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party in Canada. The men, who were in Canada to play in an ice hockey tournament, have been granted bail with unusual conditions, including surrendering their passports and residing at a Canadian naval base. The sailors are accused of sexually assaulting a local woman in her early 20s after a hockey game. They are facing serious charges and could face up to 14 years in prison if convicted. The British and Canadian authorities are cooperating in the investigation.

A mother, Valerie Jackson, was shocked to find herself surrounded by armed police while out shopping with her son, RJ, who has a rare skin disease called Netherton's Syndrome. The syndrome causes RJ's skin to appear red and scaly, which a member of the public mistook for signs of abuse, leading them to report Valerie for child abuse. Valerie, who is from Las Vegas, explained that RJ's condition requires her to regularly apply creams and Vaseline to his skin to prevent dryness and ease pain. Despite the challenges, Valerie adores her son and sees him as a beautiful boy with a bubbly personality. She also shared her experiences of facing ignorance, taunts, and criticism from others who do not understand RJ's condition.

Campaigners against the Protein World 'Are You Beach Body Ready?' adverts, featuring a bikini-clad model, have celebrated as Transport for London (TfL) removes the posters from the London Underground. The adverts caused controversy among feminists and body image campaigners, with a Change.org petition gaining over 50,000 signatures and the Advertising Standards Authority receiving more than 200 complaints. Despite Protein World defending their campaign, TfL's decision to remove the posters was influenced by customer feedback, and a planned protest against the adverts is expected to draw a large crowd. The controversy has sparked a backlash on social media, with thousands of critical tweets, and prominent figures such as TV presenter Susanna Reid describing the campaign as 'anxiety-inducing'.

Rail companies are facing criticism for planning significant fare increases shortly after the general election, despite promises from political party leaders to freeze or cap prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has intervened, requesting that First Great Western reconsider their decision to nearly double fares on a route passing through his constituency. Other train companies are also introducing sharp price hikes, with unregulated fares seeing the most significant increases. This has prompted concern from passengers and criticism from consumer websites, especially as it comes at a time when fare freezes have been widely discussed.

A 66-year-old former soldier, John Young, was left blinded in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown by vandals. The incident occurred when Mr. Young confronted a group of thugs who were throwing stones at his property in Oldham, Greater Manchester. As a result of the attack, Mr. Young suffered an open wound to his forehead and a serious eye injury, leading to permanent blindness in one eye. The retired soldier, who recently married his wife Elaine, expressed his sense of insecurity and disbelief about the unprovoked attack. The police are investigating the incident but have not identified a clear motive, suggesting it could be a case of mindless vandalism.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a one-year contract extension with the county, keeping him at the club until the end of the 2016 season. Poynton, who missed the 2014 campaign due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident, has successfully returned to action and will be available for the start of the upcoming season. The 25-year-old former England under-19 international has shown good form in training and pre-season, and his dedication and character have been praised by Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw has been given the all-clear from cancer by doctors, an incredible achievement after battling an aggressive form of the disease for a year. Harley's treatment included chemotherapy, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, which he faced with bravery and resilience. He donned a superhero costume and decorated his radiotherapy mask like a ninja turtle to feel stronger. Harley's story inspired many, and he even received a box of ninja turtle gifts from Nickelodeon. Now cancer-free, Harley is full of energy and will continue to have regular check-ups to ensure the disease hasn't returned. His father, Oliver, shared their joy and excitement for the future. Neuroblastoma, the type of cancer Harley had, is a rare form of cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK each year. It originates in nerve cells and can spread to various parts of the body. Treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, antibody treatment, and radiotherapy.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to focus on his club career at Aston Villa and continue to impress, rather than be distracted by the decision between representing the Republic of Ireland or England internationally. Grealish's performances have sparked interest from both nations, but Sherwood believes the 19-year-old should establish himself at Villa first, highlighting his confidence and ball control. Grealish's father, Kevin, concurs, stating that international opportunities will come if Jack maintains his form for Villa, acknowledging the difficult decision ahead.

Private jet travel is a luxury industry, with high landing fees at certain airports. The busiest periods for private jet travel are during major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix, with round-trip flights costing up to $54,000. Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, charges the highest landing fees at $6,850. Unexpected appearances in the top 10 most expensive airports for landing fees include Bristol Airport in the UK, Dublin Airport in Ireland, and Salzburg Airport in Austria.

A video of a Labrador named Cooper eating an ice cream cone in one bite while his pal Daisy takes her time has gone viral with over seven million views. Owner Katie Gallegos from Oregon, who runs a dog resort, defends giving her dogs the weekly treat, stating that Cooper is an athlete in amazing health. The duo also enjoys "Pup-uccinos" from Starbucks, with Cooper typically gobbling them down.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock, signing a three-year deal. The former assistant boss, who took over as interim manager in February, has impressed with just one loss in seven games.

A Florida mother has accused her son's school of threatening to suspend him due to the use of essential oils, which she applies to help manage his autism. The school claims the oils are a distraction due to their strong scent, while the mother argues they have a positive impact on her son's behavior and are a natural alternative to chemicals. The school district has since retracted the suspension, acknowledging it as a health issue. The family uses DoTerra brand oils with fragrances like lavender and chamomile, marketed as powerfully fragrant.

A fire destroyed 90 beach-side condos in Westhampton on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings, and smoke could be seen from 3 miles away. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the fire but could not enter the building. The cause of the fire is unknown and is being investigated.

The Queen, a longtime equestrian and horse breeder, was spotted riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park as she approached her 89th birthday. The Queen, who has never worn a riding helmet, reportedly chooses not to wear one because of her hair. Despite reducing the time she spends riding due to a knee injury, the Queen remains an enthusiastic rider and is often seen at her Windsor stables. She also breeds several horse and pony breeds, including Fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud, and owns thoroughbred racehorses. The Queen's first pony was a Shetland named Peggy, given to her when she was four years old, sparking a lifelong passion for equines.

A long-standing dispute over noise levels between two Brisbane neighbors ended fatally, with 55-year-old Leon Yeaman dying from a single punch landed by his 28-year-old neighbor, shift worker Phillip Pama. The incident occurred on Thursday night, with Yeaman creating a disturbance in his yard and Pama, who was sleeping before a shift, confronting him. Pama's lawyer claimed his client acted blindly in the moment, throwing a punch while being pushed. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene, and Pama, charged with manslaughter, was granted conditional bail.

Jilted music teacher Yulia Simonova, 52, wanted to hire a hitman to torture and murder 15-year-old pupil Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship. She offered £1,400 to a friend to find someone to carry out the act, but was instead set up with an undercover police officer. Simonova was filmed describing her desires to inflict pain on the boy and was subsequently arrested and charged with attempted murder, facing up to 15 years in prison.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, has shared that he maintains a strong faith in God and prays daily, but refrains from discussing football in his conversations with God or his wife, Matilde Faria. Mourinho values the separation between his professional and family life and believes in supporting people beyond his role in competitive sports.

Bob Barker, the legendary host of *The Price is Right*, made a surprise return to the show on April 1, hosting the first price-guessing game "Lucky Seven" at the age of 91. Barker hosted the TV game show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, and his brief return delighted fans and contestants alike.

"A Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. for attempted burglary and destruction of property. He was taken into custody by the Metropolitan Police and later had his security clearance revoked and was put on leave. Baldwin worked for the Foreign Missions Branch, attached to the State Department. His arrest comes amid other incidents of misconduct by the agency's personnel, including a supervisor and two high-ranking officials, which have reflected negatively on the organization responsible for protecting the President and their family."

A brave freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, aged 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life by getting up close to a hungry lion to capture stunning images. He left the safety of his car and crept within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to get the perfect shot. Unfortunately, the sound of his camera alerted the lion, forcing Mr. Saeed to retreat rapidly. Reflecting on the incident, Mr. Saeed acknowledged the danger he faced and the intense encounter with the lion.

New York City police are seeking the public's help in identifying an unconscious woman who died on a Brooklyn street on March 22. The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, had no identification but bore a distinctive tattoo: the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. NYPD has released images of the tattoo, hoping that someone will recognize it and provide information about the woman's identity. The cause of death is yet to be determined, pending a medical examiner's report.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, unable to afford traditional housing, built a unique home on the back of a flatbed truck. Over a year and a half, they crafted a solar-powered, two-bedroom residence with a steel frame, aromatic cypress wood interior, and modern amenities. Their innovative home, surrounded by nature in Nelson, allows them to live almost self-sufficiently, with water sourced from a spring and electricity generated by solar panels. The total cost of their labor of love was approximately $25,000.

Research has found that children who share iPads in class perform better in early literacy tests than those who do not have access to the devices. The study, conducted by Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University in the US, showed that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class over an academic year scored significantly higher than their peers in classes without iPads or where each student had their own device. The findings suggest that collaborative learning around technology may be a key factor in enhancing literacy outcomes.

A piglet born with only its front legs has gone viral online for its ability to walk and balance on just two legs. The young animal, nicknamed "Super Pig," belongs to a farmer in southwestern China and has captured hearts with its determination and unique skill. The piglet mixes well with its fully-abled littermates and has become a local attraction, with villagers gathering to witness its extraordinary balance and heartwarming spirit.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by a car. Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was hit by Francesco Dracone's car as he exited his pit box on lap 25. Phillips received treatment for a cut on his leg and was released. Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd. The race was challenging for many drivers due to traction issues caused by rain.

CCTV footage has been released of 32-year-old Milton Vieira Severiano attacking his wife, 29-year-old dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, in their apartment garden in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Severiano dragged de Sena's body outside, bashed her head into concrete paving 11 times, punched her in the face 10 times, and then shot her in the face five times at point-blank range. He confessed to the murder, stating he was jealous of men looking at his wife, who was a member of a dance troupe. A neighbour, Lelio Maya Puga, recalled hearing the couple's argument and Severiano accusing his wife of being promiscuous. After the shooting, Severiano stole a car but was arrested after crashing it. Police found multiple guns and a bulletproof vest in his possession. He now faces life in prison.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, 41, known for her best-selling book *I Quit Sugar*, has revealed her personal struggle with mental illness. In an intimate interview, Wilson shared how anxiety and a combination of stressors led her to a point of considering ending her life. She felt alone and couldn't see a way forward, highlighting the link between anxiety and depression. Wilson has since come to terms with her anxiety, accepting it as part of who she is, and wants to raise awareness of the growing number of Australian women facing similar challenges.

Elena Curtin of Portland, Oregon, who was seven months pregnant at the time, will no longer be prosecuted for beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin, who is now 23, was charged with second-degree assault but prosecutors dropped the charge because she was "justified in her outrage." When Curtin came home, she found her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend, who was allegedly jealous and bitter, using heroin in her bathroom and refused to leave, leading to the assault. With the defense of Oregon's legal allowance for the use of force against intruders, Curtin avoided a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years if convicted.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed reacting with disgust to being fed broccoli by her owner. She spit the vegetable out, showing her dislike for it. Other videos show Gemma enjoying treats, sleeping, and spending time with her family. The dog lives with two children, and the hope is that they will not follow her example when it comes to eating their greens.

HSBC has issued an apology after a link on its website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link, which was supposed to lead to a page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, had not been updated since the awards were discontinued in 2011, and subsequently led to an explicit website. HSBC has since removed the link and denied any association with the external site, assuring customers that their banking services and website remain secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, calmly called 911 when a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home, with him and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, trapped on the second floor. During the 11-minute call, he provided clear instructions to firefighters and soothed his sister, telling her they would be okay. Firefighters were able to rescue both children by breaking a window to their bedroom, with Veteran Firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward leading the charge. The siblings were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, and the rest of the family escaped safely.

Amazing pictures have emerged of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, with photographer Andy Hutchinson capturing the neon glow of millions of plankton lighting up Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. A similar display was seen in Sydney in 2014, with an oceanography expert explaining that the glow is caused by noctiluca scintillans, a type of phytoplankton that emits light as a defense mechanism.

New genetic tests can identify breast cancer patients who may not need chemotherapy, sparing them the difficult side effects of the treatment. These tests determine the aggressiveness of the tumor and provide an accurate prediction of the risk of the disease returning. The majority of breast cancer patients are usually given chemotherapy after surgery to prevent recurrence, but experts believe that for some women, the risk of cancer returning is low and chemotherapy may not be necessary. The tests, such as endopredict, can help patients make informed choices about their treatment options.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

"A total of 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with one ship, HMS Ocean, recording five emergency 'medevac' operations in the last nine years. Data revealed that 18 other ships had similar incidents, with a strict 'no-touching' rule suggesting conception occurred before deployment or during leave. This news follows the replacement of Commander Sarah West, the first female captain of a Royal Navy warship, amid claims of an onboard relationship. Historically, women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and their presence in submarines and other military roles has been increasing. However, strict rules prohibit pregnant servicewomen from serving in war zones, leading to evacuations from Afghanistan and Iraq."

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was discovered on the roof of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence in Tokyo. This incident has raised concerns about the potential for drone-related terrorism in Japan, especially with upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. The discovery coincided with a court approval for restarting nuclear reactors, a decision unpopular with many Japanese citizens due to safety concerns. Investigators are working to determine the origin of the drone, which was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and the radioactive substance.

A security guard from Zhejiang Province, China, rides his 84-year-old mother, who has Alzheimer's, to work every day on his motorbike. Lu Xincai is afraid his mother will get lost if left alone, so he takes her with him, ensuring her safety with a sash around their waists. The journey to work takes an hour, and even at work, Mr. Lu ensures his mother is safe and doesn't wander off. He feels a duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to her children, and finds peace in seeing her safe.

Here is a concise summary of the passage: 

According to a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, heavy and binge drinking among Americans increased significantly between 2005 and 2012, with a 17.2% rise attributed mainly to increasing rates among women. The study, published in the American Journal of Public Health, defines heavy drinking and binge drinking based on daily and single-occasion consumption for women and men. Researchers found that social norm changes, particularly those related to women's drinking habits, are major drivers of this trend. Despite the increase in heavy drinking, the percentage of people consuming any alcohol has remained stable. The study also highlights the economic and public health impacts of excessive alcohol consumption, with high associated costs and an increase in alcoholism treatment seekers. Experts offer cultural and economic explanations, including changing social norms, increased affordability, targeted advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies, to explain the rise in drinking rates across the nation.

UN officials and the World Health Organization warn that doctors are endangering the health of women and their babies by performing caesarean sections too frequently. They recommend that the procedure be limited to medically necessary cases, citing risks of infection and other health complications, as well as the higher cost to the NHS compared to natural births. This advice contradicts current NHS guidelines, which offer women caesareans even without medical justification, contributing to a rising rate of caesarean sections in England.

A woman, Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested on April 17 for breaking into a $800,000 home on Martha's Vineyard and selling the owner's possessions. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny, and malicious destruction of property. The owner, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins in the living room, and she claimed ownership of the house before fleeing. She was arrested later that day when she returned to the scene. A construction worker reported seeing Filkins holding a yard sale with the stolen items. Police are now seeking the return of the stolen items and offer assistance to those who unknowingly purchased them.

Police reunited a lost iPhone with its owner, Bella Crooke, after finding it unlocked and posting a series of humorous photos and puns on Bella's Facebook page. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station, and officers used the phone to post selfies and jokes, telling Bella she could collect her phone and that she should put a password on it. The post was shared by Bella's friends, who praised the police for their unusual approach. Bella eventually reclaimed her phone and thanked the officers for their sense of humor.

These shocking images capture the tragic moment a five-day-old baby hippopotamus was accidentally killed during a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa. The calf's mother tried to protect her baby by staying with her herd, but unfortunately, the young hippo strayed into the path of the fighting males. It was grabbed and hurled through the air, suffering fatal injuries. Despite the mother's efforts to rescue her calf, it died hours later.

A three-bedroom apartment in the exclusive area of Knightsbridge, London, has been listed on the market for £575,000, significantly lower than neighboring properties. However, the catch is that the lease has only three years remaining, resulting in a high cost per year or month. The property is described as spacious and well-appointed but requires modernization. If the lease is extended, the apartment could be worth over £6 million. Estate agents have received significant interest and warn potential buyers of the costly lease extension process. The unique opportunity has attracted locals, developers, and end users alike.

A computer outage at 8,000 Starbucks stores across the US and Canada resulted in registers being unable to process credit card transactions or sales. As a result, baristas gave away free drinks and baked goods to customers before closing early for the night. Excited Twitter users shared news of the giveaway, with some praising the opportunity for free Starbucks items and others taking advantage of the situation. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, was resolved by the following Saturday, with stores resuming normal operations. The incident occurred just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings.

Here is a concise summary of the passage: 

Terrorist training and radicalization activities are taking place in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to a Wales Extremism and Counter-Terrorism Unit officer, Detective Constable Gareth Jones. DC Jones highlighted that these areas are being used for radicalization and training, and those involved blend into the community while hiding their true intentions. Wales has a history of Islamic extremist activity, including incidents linked to hate preacher Abu Hamza and the 7/7 bombers. The region's rugged terrain is ideal for military training and has unfortunately also attracted terrorists looking to prepare for attacks. Community intelligence is vital to countering these threats, DC Jones emphasized.

A rare Omura's whale, initially feared extinct, was found on a beach in Western Australia, offering scientists a unique opportunity to study the little-known species. This is the first recording of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The juvenile female measured 5.68 meters and was identified using DNA profiling. With its sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, the discovery provides valuable insights into the distribution and characteristics of Omura's whales, typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and potential public display.

The passage discusses the influence of hormones on presidential candidates' decision-making, particularly the bias against female candidates like Hillary Clinton. Cheryl Rios, a CEO, claims that Clinton's hormones might make her irrational and unfit for presidency, while ignoring historical evidence of male leaders' impaired judgment due to hormones. Studies show that women leaders take fewer risks, and examples of cheating male politicians support the argument against hormone-based bias. Time magazine's proclamation of Clinton being the "perfect" age to be president due to her postmenopausal status highlights the issue. The bias against women in the workplace, evident in corporate boards and student-professor interactions, remains a significant barrier for female candidates. The election of a female president would be a step towards equality, benefiting the nation, economy, and families. The passage concludes by refuting Rios' claim that a female should not be president, noting that Canada had a female prime minister in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is auctioning off his extensive collection of antiques, valued at £100,000, as he downsizes his home. The collection includes over 200 items, such as a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, Victorian furniture, a portrait of himself with a longbow, medieval weapons, antique books, and crystal chandeliers. The auction will be held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, and Mr. Hardy, a keen military historian and student of English literature, has expressed sadness at parting with his treasured possessions.

Michael Scott Shemansky has been named a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, and was last seen fleeing their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida, on Saturday. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was discovered. Authorities have not confirmed the cause of death but have the murder weapon in their possession. Neighbors and family members suggest that divorce proceedings and a history of mental health issues may have contributed to the incident. Shemansky is considered dangerous, and anyone with information is urged to contact the police.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been chosen to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships, despite usually requiring a bidding process. This decision was made by the IAAF council, who saw it as a strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Previously, Eugene had failed to secure the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF president, Lamine Diack, justified the decision by stating it was a unique opportunity with strong support from public authorities, the private sector, and an enthusiastic public.

Leonie Granger, an aspiring model, has been sentenced to 16 years in prison for her role in a honey trap that led to the death of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger targeted Hassan, flashing a roll of £50 notes at a casino. She used her looks to befriend and gain his trust, receiving gifts, cash, and expensive dinners in return. On the night of the murder, Granger left Hassan's flat, letting her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and his accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, inside. They tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and stole his winnings. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter but not murder, while her accomplices were convicted of murder and received life sentences. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked."

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas has experienced a dip in form during the latter stages of the season, which has raised questions about his durability. After an impressive start to the campaign, the 27-year-old's performance has declined, evident in Spain's recent 2-0 defeat to Holland. Fabregas, who captained Spain, struggled to make an impact and was criticized by the Spanish media. This follows a similar pattern observed by his former club, Barcelona, who noted a "downward trend" in his statistics as the season progresses. Despite this, Fabregas remains an important player for Chelsea, and his contributions will be crucial in their remaining games as they aim to secure the Premier League title.

West Ham are pursuing Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who has impressed during a two-week trial with their academy. The 17-year-old, regarded as one of the Caribbean's top prospects, has also attracted interest from Belgian clubs. As West Ham negotiate a deal, the club has also announced that season tickets for the 2016-17 season at the Olympic Stadium will start from £289, aiming to fill the 54,000 capacity with the Premier League's cheapest ticket pricing.

Huntsman Mike Lane, 40, was assaulted by balaclava-clad protesters with iron bars on ropes, causing concussion, broken teeth, and swelling. Wiltshire Police have dropped the investigation due to insufficient evidence, despite having a video, car registration numbers, and names of suspected saboteurs. This decision has angered Lane and hunt supporters, with some losing trust in the police. The Countryside Alliance campaigns to ban face coverings to help identify criminals.

Adam Gadahn, a prominent member of al-Qaeda and a former American citizen, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, the White House announced. Gadahn, also known as "Azzam the American," was known for his many statements on behalf of the terrorist organization and had risen through the ranks to become its chief English-language propagandist. He was indicted for treason and material support to al-Qaeda in 2006 and was among the FBI's most wanted terrorists. In al-Qaeda videos, Gadahn urged Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests and made threats against the U.S. and its allies. He played an increasingly prominent role within the organization, including advising on media strategy.

Chinese parents are known for their ambition in fostering child prodigies, and the country's latest viral sensation is a five-year-old basketball prodigy named Mai Zizhuo. Mai has showcased exceptional basketball skills in a video that has captivated China, with smooth dribbling and confident shooting. His talents have earned him widespread admiration and a substantial online following. Netizens expressed disbelief and awe, with some jokingly questioning their own abilities in comparison to Mai's prowess.

Tom O'Carroll, a former activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, set up in the wake of the phone-hacking scandal, campaigns against the Independent Press Standards Organisation. They are calling for a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. The presence of O'Carroll, who campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s, is an embarrassment for Hacked Off.

The daily swimmers at Bondi's Icebergs Club were displaced on Thursday as the pool was drained and transformed into a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The club's iconic pool provided a stunning backdrop for the Ten Pieces presentation, a lifestyle brand that creates unisex collections of ten pieces designed to be worn in multiple ways. Models showcased the monochrome creations against the beautiful ocean view, while guests enjoyed refreshments and sunny weather. Beachgoers and passers-by stopped to watch the unusual fashion show, a unique collision of worlds.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, enjoyed a day at a Northern California safari park with his family. He fed and posed with a rare white tiger and also took photos with giraffes and sea lions. The 28-year-old was accompanied by his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and their daughter, Lamysa. Khan also recently announced his next boxing match, which will be against Chris Algieri on May 30.

The name of Palestinian teenager Mohammed Abu Khdeir will be removed from an Israeli memorial wall, following complaints from his family and others. The wall commemorates fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism, but Abu Khdeir's family objected to his inclusion as he was killed by three Israelis in a rogue attack. The organization Almagor, representing Israeli victims of terror, supported the family's position and threatened to remove the names of their own family members if Abu Khdeir was not removed. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, has agreed to remove the teenager's name.

A young boy prefers to use his pet cat's belly as a pillow rather than a conventional feather-down one. The boy's father, Lionel Hutz, filmed the boy chasing the cat around the garden, attempting to rest on the cat. This playful pursuit concludes with the cat wandering indoors, having had enough. However, the duo quickly reconcile, with the boy gently feeding treats to the cat.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, has lost his coaching job at a private academy after admitting to selling marijuana. Kushner is one of over a dozen ex-drug dealers testifying against undercover officers, accusing them of stealing cash and drugs during a 2007 arrest. He had concealed his criminal history from his employers and passed a background check. Kushner's testimony reveals a pattern of alleged police wrongdoing, with officers facing charges including racketeering, extortion, robbery, and drug dealing.

An explosion at a controversial chemical plant in China's Fujian province injured six people and sparked a massive fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility, with no reported toxic chemical spills. Protests against PX plants have occurred in several Chinese cities due to pollution and health concerns, leading to the relocation of the Zhangzhou plant to a more remote location.

Jack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager, has stated that he will continue to wear his socks low during Premier League matches due to superstition. Grealish, who made his first Premier League start on Tuesday night, wears children's shinpads and keeps his stockings just above the roll of his shinpads. Despite some referees telling him to pull his socks up, Grealish insists that he will not change his sock habit. He is pleased to have made his first start for Villa, calling it a "big relegation scrap", and hopes to gain a few more starts before the end of the season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of singers Bobby Brown and the late Whitney Houston, is reported to have irreversible brain damage, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, Bobbi Kristina remains unresponsive and her condition has not changed significantly in three months. This contradicts previous statements made by her father, Bobby Brown, who claimed she was awake and watching him. Lawyers for the Brown family have stated that Bobbi Kristina's condition has improved, but the quality of her life remains uncertain as she embarks on a long and challenging rehabilitation process.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova beat Sabine Lisicki and Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges. With a mix of powerful play and errors from Lisicki, Pavlyuchenkova came back from a first-set loss and a match point down in the second set to win. Russia needs one more win to reach the Fed Cup final and claim their first title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, Australia, are being warned of potential flooding and damage due to an upcoming storm, following wild weather the previous week. Meteorologists predict an east coast low, bringing heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned about the impact on the already affected regions, with over 4,000 jobs still pending from the last storm. The weather system is expected to affect coastal areas in the state's north-east, with intense rainfall and strong winds. The SES is urging residents to prepare themselves and their homes, while also trying to complete as many pending jobs as possible before the next storm hits.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" music video, denied claims that she attempted suicide. Moric stated that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure and a fall that caused bruising and a head injury. She refuted Italian media reports and her boyfriend's suggestions that she tried to take her own life, reassuring her fans that she is recovering at home and only needs rest. Moric expressed shock at the suicide claims and emphasized that she had no such intentions. The model, with over 40,000 Instagram followers, shared photos of her injuries and clarified the incident's details. Previously, in 2009, Italian media had also reported a similar suicide attempt by Moric, which she claimed was due to low blood pressure. The passage also mentions Moric's former marriage to renowned paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

As Kate and William await their second child, a new poll suggests the British public favours traditional names, with Diana—a tribute to William's late mother—being the top choice for a girl. Alice and Charlotte are also preferred, honouring the Queen's aunt and William's father, respectively. For a boy, James is the most popular choice, with Alexander as the second favourite. The poll also showed support for William's decision to take paternity leave.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, Afghanistan, killing 17 and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The protesters were on their way to a rally against the provincial governor when the attack occurred at 10 a.m. local time. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other organization has claimed responsibility as of yet.

Dani Alves, the 31-year-old Brazilian right-back, is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting their final contract offer. Despite a successful seven-year spell at the club, which included winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, Alves has been unable to agree on new terms with the Catalan club. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed the decision at a press conference on Thursday, stating that the offer of a three-year extension, dependent on playing time, was not acceptable. With negotiations now over, Alves will be leaving the Nou Camp at the end of the season.

Pablo Osvaldo, who is currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo believes that the duo's playing style would be a perfect fit for Boca Juniors and that they would be adored by the fans at La Bombonera.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, suffered a spectacular fall from his horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton. The incident, which saw Ferguson perform a double somersault, has gained significant attention online. Despite the ordeal, Ferguson walked away with just a minor cut on his nose and returned to his regular duties at Paul Nicholls's yard the next morning. Ferguson described the fall as "a blur" and expressed gratitude for his luck, taking the incident in stride with good humor.

England rugby player and London Wasps captain James Haskell dressed up as Iron Man to celebrate the release of *Avengers: Age of Ultron*, posting a photo of his costume on Instagram. The photo was shared ahead of the movie's premiere at Westfield London, which was attended by A-list stars including Robert Downey Jr., who portrays Iron Man in the film. Haskell, who returned to the Wasps in 2012 after playing rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand, has now made over 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England.

Wide-leg trousers are a prominent trend for the upcoming season, offering a fresh alternative to the ubiquitous skinny jean. This style, as seen on Louise Redknapp and showcased by brands like Gucci and Topshop, flatters all body types when paired with a simple knit or shirt and high-heeled shoes. Denim is an accessible way to embrace this trend, as demonstrated by Gucci's vintage-washed flares. Celebrities like Poppy Delevingne have also embraced this look, appearing at the AW15 Chloe show in Paris donning this trend.

The University of Michigan faced opposition from students regarding their plan to screen *American Sniper* as part of a series of social events. Over 200 students petitioned against it, citing negative depictions of the Middle East and its people in the film's portrayal of the Iraq War. However, there was also a backlash to the initial decision to cancel, and a counter-petition emerged. Ultimately, the university decided to proceed with the screening, citing freedom of expression and respect for students' choices. The announcement was well-received by notable figures, including the university's football coach.

Two French tourists have been charged with animal cruelty after allegedly trying to set a Quokka on fire with an aerosol spray and a lighter on Rottnest Island, off the coast of Perth, Australia. The little creature survived but was singed by the flame. Detectives seized video evidence and questioned the men, who were evicted from the island and are due to appear in court on April 17. Quokkas are small marsupials native to some Australian islands, including Rottnest and Bald Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer, was able to relive her glory days through a special video compilation of early music videos, known as "soundies." With the help of filmmakers and volunteers, Barker, who performed in renowned New York clubs alongside notable entertainers, was able to see herself dancing for the first time. Having never seen any motion pictures or photographs of her performances, this opportunity brought her immense delight.

A recent survey by OSV found that car washing, once a common tradition in Britain, is declining, with a third of men and three-quarters of women admitting they never wash their cars themselves. This is attributed to various factors, including the availability of hand car washes, larger vehicle sizes, and busier lifestyles. The survey also revealed regional differences in car washing habits and the likelihood of washing certain car brands.

Martin Skrtel has praised the influence of Steven Gerrard on his career and believes the Liverpool captain's departure will significantly change the club. Skrtel, who was signed in 2008, credits Gerrard for helping him settle at Liverpool and sees him as one of the best players in the world. While acknowledging the challenge, Skrtel believes Liverpool can replace Gerrard and has faith in the potential replacements. Both players are set to return to the lineup for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Gerrard aiming to end his Liverpool career on a high by reaching the final and beating Arsenal.

At 75 years old, golf legend Jack Nicklaus, also known as the Golden Bear, achieved a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This feat, on the 130-yard fourth hole, added a magical moment to his illustrious career. Nicklaus, who first won a green jacket in 1963 and remains the only person to have won six, joined an exclusive club of five men who have achieved the career grand slam. On a day with five hole-in-ones, including two by Colombia's Camilo Villegas, Nicklaus' achievement stood out, thrilling the crowd and his playing partners, Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw.

Severe weather, including tornadoes, hail, and flooding, impacted multiple states across the Midwest on Wednesday night and Thursday. Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, with additional storms moving through the state. The National Weather Service also received indications of a potential tornado in Potosi, Missouri, with reports of wind damage and flooding in the area. Social media users in Missouri shared photos and videos of the storm's impact, including downed trees, roof damage, and flooded streets. Chad Myers, a CNN severe weather expert, warned of the deadly nature of nighttime tornadoes. The severe weather system is expected to continue affecting the Midwest, the Mississippi River Valley, the Tennessee River Valley, and the southern Great Lakes region on Thursday.

A 73-year-old reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of Eric Harris. Bates claims he accidentally shot Harris with his gun instead of stunning him with a taser during a weapons sting operation. The judge allowed Bates to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, which prompted a response from Harris' family, who criticized Bates' apparent lack of remorse. Bates' training and qualifications have been called into question, with allegations of preferential treatment due to his donations and connections. His lawyers maintain that he had proper law enforcement training and have released his training documents. The preliminary hearing is set for July 2nd.

Conor McGregor has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach ahead of his featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. The Irish fighter already has a gorilla eating a heart tattooed on his chest. McGregor claims he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo, who will be defending his belt for the eighth time. The pair have a fractious relationship, with McGregor previously grabbing Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has come under fire from anti-drinking campaigners after he was filmed skolling a beer at a sporting event. While some have criticised Mr Abbott for glorifying binge drinking and promoting a masculine culture associated with heavy alcohol consumption, others have defended his actions as a harmless display of Australian tradition. Health Minister Sussan Ley supported Mr Abbott, arguing that his focus on fitness and active lifestyle set a positive example for the country. This incident has sparked a debate about changing attitudes towards binge drinking and the responsibility of political figures in influencing social norms.

There has been a significant rise in HIV cases in Indiana, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County, an area typically seeing around 5 cases per year. This outbreak has been linked to intravenous drug use, specifically involving the drug Opana. In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program, providing over 5,000 clean syringes and collecting used ones. Despite opposition to needle exchanges as a potential promoter of drug use, the program has gained support from health officials and some lawmakers, who recognize its effectiveness in reducing harm and preventing disease outbreaks. With growing HIV cases, there are calls for extending the program and implementing similar initiatives in other counties. However, funding and long-term sustainability concerns remain, especially without public funding.

An Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take an exam about the football club, quizzing her on players, matches, and the club's history. Saskia shared the test on Twitter, showing her impressive score of 43.5/50, or 87%. While some praised the couple's passion, others criticized the boyfriend for taking it too far. The story sparked varied reactions, with some men inspired to test their partners and others critical of extreme fandom.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked as an informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. Having fled Colombia in the 1980s due to cartel connections, Toro provided valuable information to the DEA, aiding in the prosecution of high-profile figures such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, Toro has not received citizenship and is facing deportation, which he believes will result in his death. DEA agent Mike McManus and a former colleague have spoken in support of Toro, with the latter providing him with $5,000 for an operation. Toro's current status is uncertain as he seeks a green card or passport and faces the risk of returning to Colombia.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after being allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village. She is now fighting for her life in a hospital with 70% burns. The accused men have been arrested, but the girl's family reportedly told her to stay quiet about the attack. This incident adds to a series of recent sexual assaults in India that have sparked protests and calls for better protection for women. There is heightened sensitivity to the issue, with officials banning a documentary about a notorious gang rape and murder case.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has stated that he dreams of beating rivals Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford, aiming to secure a top-three finish and automatic Champions League qualification. Van Gaal has ruled out Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw from the fixture, deeming them unfit despite their return to training. United's good form and City's recent defeat present an opportunity for United to climb the table. Van Gaal acknowledges the challenge posed by City and emphasizes the importance of controlling aggression in such games. He also expresses his appreciation for the support of United's fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against ticket price hikes at the Premier League clash at Emirates Stadium, with empty seats and banners displaying their discontent. With tickets starting from £64, fans from both clubs united to raise awareness of the financial struggles, calling for reductions to match working-class incomes. The protest comes after a lucrative TV rights deal, highlighting the growing gap between the league's revenue and affordable match attendance.

A newborn baby, Star Reader, was diagnosed with a life-threatening liver condition, biliary atresia, shortly after birth. With neither of her parents being a suitable match for a liver transplant, her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader, offered part of her liver, successfully saving her niece's life. Star's parents noticed their daughter's skin had a yellow tinge, indicating jaundice, which led to the discovery of blocked bile ducts. Biliary atresia affects approximately 1 in 16,000 babies and can be fatal if left untreated. Star underwent the transplant surgery in November and has since recovered well, now living a normal life.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian took part in Audi's football challenge. The challenges included firing balls into car boots from close and long ranges, playing tennis over an Audi R8 V10 Plus worth £127,000, and long-range shooting. Hazard and Ake dominated the first two rounds, but Remy and Willian made a comeback and won the final challenge, despite Willian accidentally smashing a wing mirror during their victory.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a highway crash in New Hampshire in December 2013, killing a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. During his sentencing, Dellinger denied being suicidal, contradicting previous claims by prosecutors. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. Dellinger's defense attributed the crash to Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis symptoms. The victims' families were present in the courtroom, with Dellinger's wife expressing devastation and offering condolences.

Lacey Spears, of Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder in the death of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, and sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger and hope that Spears would die in prison, highlighting her lack of emotion during the sentencing. Spears was found to have loaded her son's feeding tube with a lethal amount of salt while he was hospitalized, and prosecutors argued that she sought attention through her son's illnesses. Despite the defense's claims of innocence and plans to appeal, the judge and prosecutors emphasized Spears' mental illness and the cruel nature of the crime.

Here is a concise summary of the passage: 

An improved influenza vaccination will be available in Australia, addressing two new strains, Influenza A H3N2 and Influenza B B/Phuket, which caused increased deaths in the Northern Hemisphere. The new vaccine will be available from April 20, and experts recommend everyone receive it for protection, especially those in high-risk groups. The delay in stock arrival is due to the inclusion of these two new strains, and individuals are advised to book their flu shots promptly.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism from National Geographic Magazine, which described the site as underwhelming and lacking historical character. This critique comes at a sensitive time, as Illinois faces financial difficulties and potential cuts to the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb. Supporters of the site refute the magazine's portrayal, highlighting recent repairs and renovations, and expressing concern about the impact of potential budget cuts on the management and accessibility of this important historical monument.

Nineties and noughties fashion is experiencing a revival, with chokers, berry lips, and Calvin Klein logo shirts trending. However, some trends from these decades, like JNCO "rave" jeans and bucket hats, are sparking controversy. Other questionable comebacks include camouflage print, excessive trends, Ugg boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, harem trousers, and more. Celebrities are embracing or shunning these retro styles, sparking debates about what should be left in the past.

- The Kardashians, particularly Kylie Jenner, sparked a new trend of lip plumping using a jar, with the hashtag #KylieJennerChallenge.
