- Ewan McGregor joins the cast of 'Beauty and the Beast' as Lumiere, while Johnny Depp's transformative look in the 'Black Mass' trailer has sparked interest. 
- A military dad's original photo announcement of his pregnancy referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." 
- Finally, a heartwarming story of a military dad photobombing his son's picture earned praise for its creativity.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory and progression to the semi-finals of the Miami Open with a giant cake, following her win over Sabine Lisicki. Williams' hopes of facing sister Venus were dashed by her surprise defeat to Carla Suarez Navarro. Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals, after Halep's victory over Sloane Stephens. Andy Murray also received a celebratory cake for his 500th win.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent Pakistani human rights activist and owner of the Second Floor cafe in Karachi, was shot and killed by gunmen after hosting a discussion group on the topic of disappearances and mass abductions in the province of Baluchistan. Mahmud was known for her fearless advocacy of free speech, women's entrepreneurship, and progressive values in a country where such topics are often dangerous to address openly. Her death shocked the nation and highlighted the risks faced by those speaking out against human rights abuses and seeking a more tolerant and secular Pakistan. Despite the dangers, Mahmud remained steadfast in her beliefs and provided a space for like-minded individuals to gather and exchange ideas. Her legacy inspires those who continue to strive for a fairer and more just Pakistan.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer, is one of thousands of refugees who fled to Indian Kashmir almost 70 years ago after the partition of India. Despite living in India's only Muslim-majority state for most of his life, Ram is still denied citizenship rights and is unable to own property or vote. However, with the recent success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party in a state vote, refugees like Ram are hopeful that their plight will finally be addressed. Around 100,000 people are classified as West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), most of whom have never set foot in Pakistan but are stuck in poverty due to their refugee status. The reluctance of state governments to grant full rights to the WPRs is believed to be due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance in the Muslim-majority state. With a new Hindu nationalist party in power, there is hope for change, but a veteran activist warns that the community is ready to take matters into their own hands if their demands are not met.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Chelsea, who have reportedly offered £4 million for the Japanese international. Muto is keen to join a club where he will receive regular playing time and develop as a player. Chelsea's potential signing of Muto has sparked interest due to the club's recent sponsorship deal with a Japanese company, with manager Jose Mourinho acknowledging the player's potential and the commercial interests at play. Muto's former boss at FC Tokyo, Ranko Popovic, praised his intelligence, speed, and strong character, calling him an "amazing" prospect. The 22-year-old is weighing his options carefully, wanting to find the right fit for his development.

Australia has been commended for reversing its policy of excluding players based outside of the country from national team selection. This decision highlights the importance of selecting the best players regardless of where they play, as seen with Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell's performances for Toulon. Similar calls are now being made for England's rugby team to follow suit, with comparisons drawn to football and the FA's selection policy. The upcoming World Cup is a key factor, as England aim to field their strongest team and avoid regrets. The improved performances of Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon, and Jonny Wilkinson while playing in France are cited as further evidence to support this argument.

The Firechat app enables users to chat with friends without an internet or mobile signal by utilizing wireless mesh networks. Developers at Open Garden have created Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that strengthens these networks, allowing messages to travel further. Firechat, downloaded over five million times, employs Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) and a similar Android feature to create localized networks where data is passed between devices. Greenstone extends the range of these networks and can be useful in various scenarios, including crowded events and areas without connectivity. It's currently in development, with a range of 20 feet, a one-year battery life, and the ability to store 1,000 messages.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle gave a TED talk about reclaiming the word "fat" as a positive descriptor, similar to how she describes herself as "short" and "a wife." She argues that "fat" doesn't have to be synonymous with "ugly" and that exposure to diverse body types can lead to more acceptance and preference for different body types. Studies support this, showing that size discrimination in the workplace has increased, and body image issues start at a young age for girls. However, Lillian's TED talk, posted on YouTube, received mostly positive feedback, indicating a shift towards embracing body diversity. She encourages others to find their "courage reference" to boost self-esteem and challenge societal norms.

Theo Walcott has been largely overlooked by Arsenal this season, spending most of his time on the substitutes' bench. Walcott and six of his Arsenal teammates have taken part in an official photoshoot for Lanvin, the club's official tailor. The 26-year-old winger will be hoping for a rare start when Arsenal faces Hull at the KC Stadium.

A collection of movie props and puppets created by special effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned off at the end of May, offering fans a chance to own a piece of Hollywood history. The collection, estimated at $746,100, includes items from *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, and *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, with some individual pieces expected to fetch over $40,000. With 417 original items spanning over 50 productions, the auction presents a unique opportunity for collectors and fans to acquire iconic pieces from beloved films.

The family of seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell, who died in a tragic accident while skiing in the French Alps, have paid an emotional tribute to him. Carwyn, an adventurous and competent skier, got separated from his family during their last ski run of the day. His mother, Ceri, and sister, Antonia, assumed he had returned to their hotel, but when he wasn't there, they raised the alarm. Unfortunately, Carwyn had veered off the piste into dense woodland and fell over a 164ft drop. His body was found by police following his footprints in the snow. The family, from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales, described Carwyn as a loving and daring boy who brought laughter to their lives. The community back in Wales is supporting the Scott-Howells, who are well-known for their farm shop.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after feeling pressured to attain a "size zero" figure. She hid food and survived on minimal calories, causing a dramatic weight loss. This led to severe health issues, including a slowed heart rate, dizziness, and ultimately, her collapse. After hospitalization and support from eating disorder organizations, Laura recovered and spoke out about the pressures contributing to her disorder. She encourages others to seek help and address the issue of body image pressures.

Liverpool FC launched its new home kit for the 2015/16 season, designed by new suppliers New Balance, who secured a £300 million four-year deal. The kit was modeled by players including Raheem Sterling, who has been the subject of transfer speculation, with Liverpool supporters expressing their desire for him to stay during the kit launch event at Anfield. The new kit features a gingham design and tributes to the Hillsborough disaster. The event also saw players discuss their upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa and the potential for silverware.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have created the largest high-definition map of dark matter, an invisible substance that does not interact with light but does exert a gravitational force, comprising 80-85% of the known universe. The map, produced using data from the Dark Energy Survey, covers 0.4% of the sky and will enable astronomers to study galaxy formation. The survey, conducted using the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, utilizes gravitational lensing to understand the distribution of dark matter and its impact on the formation of galaxies. The ultimate goal is to create a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy, covering 12.5% of the entire sky, providing insights into the nature of these mysterious entities.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old winger, Memphis Depay. United manager Louis van Gaal is familiar with Depay, having included him in the Netherlands' 2014 World Cup squad, where he scored two goals. Depay has had a prolific season at PSV, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games and winning the Eredivisie title. He is known for his pace, dribbling, and long-range shooting. PSV have confirmed interest from United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another unnamed big European club, with Depay's value having increased since Tottenham had a £15 million bid rejected last summer. Scouts and former players have compared Depay favorably to young Cristiano Ronaldo and Arjen Robben.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1 in the first leg of their youth tournament semifinal thanks to a Tammy Abraham double and a late Dominic Solanke goal. Sportsmail provides brief profiles of each player that featured in the game, highlighting their backgrounds, performances, and potential.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and senator from Florida, has stated that people are "born with a sexual preference" while maintaining that individual states should have the power to decide on the legality of gay marriage, rather than it being a constitutional right. He expressed his willingness to attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer despite disagreeing with their choice. Rubio's comments come as he launches his presidential campaign, with donors pledging monetary support exceeding the estimated $51 million required for a competitive Republican primary season.

Pablo Mandato and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Spain and Latvia, respectively, embarked on a cycling journey around the world, covering almost 7,000 miles and 16 countries in 356 days, all on a budget of less than 3 euros per person per day. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping or hosting websites, and keep costs minimal by cycling instead of using other transportation. They plan to continue their open-ended journey through Asia and eventually cycle the length of the American continent.

A Texas couple is suing their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on photo booth pictures from their 2012 wedding. The couple was unaware of the slurs until months after the wedding when the bride's sister told them. James Evans has denied the allegations and apologized but has also said that there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption. The couple's lawyer, Cathy Hale, says her clients want an apology and that they were forced to take legal action due to Evans' lack of response. Mediation is scheduled, and if an agreement is not reached, the case will go to trial in July.

England rugby player Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to his recovery from a concussion sustained in February during a game against Italy. He admits he is unsure when he will return to play for his club side Harlequins, not wanting to rush back and risk a longer-term injury. Brown's situation is similar to that of George North and Johnny Sexton, who have also suffered multiple concussions and been stood down for extended periods. Brown acknowledges the increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by World Rugby's online modules, helped him recognize the importance of not rushing his recovery.

A leading statistician, Professor David Spiegelhalter, has suggested that the increased use of smartphones and constant connectivity may be contributing to a decline in sexual frequency among British couples. Research shows a decrease in sexual frequency from five times a month in 1990 to three times a month currently. Prof. Spiegelhalter's book, *Sex by Numbers*, attributes this decline to various factors, including busier lives due to technological connections, an erosion of boundaries between work and home, and an increasing number of competing demands on time, causing sex to become a lower priority.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly valued in China with prices reaching £1.2 million, are now facing a drastic decline in popularity. This is partly due to the government's anti-corruption crackdown, as the dogs were often exchanged as gifts between wealthy businessmen and officials. In addition, weight restrictions on dog ownership in several Chinese cities and the breed's unsuitability for urban living have contributed to their decreasing demand. The oversupply of poor-quality dogs from unscrupulous breeders has further devalued the breed. As a result, Mastiffs are being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used for cheap hotpots and their skin for leather belts. Animal welfare charities are concerned about the cruel fate of these dogs, with reports of stolen pets and rescued dogs showing signs of neglect and abuse.

Every woman surveyed in Paris has experienced sexual harassment on public transport, with half assaulted before the age of 18. The poll of 600 Parisian women sparked calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains, as it revealed that gender-based harassment or assault is pervasive, often accepted as normal, and leads to women feeling excluded from public spaces. This results in women altering their daily routines and limits their freedom of movement. The report emphasizes the need to raise awareness about what constitutes sexual assault and to educate both victims and aggressors about the unacceptable nature of such behavior.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, is hosting a competition called #everydayfix, inviting groups to design products that address common issues. The three finalists are 'Snooze', an alarm clock that connects to your phone and blocks notifications for a good night's sleep; 'Forget Me Lock', a device that indicates whether your front door is locked or unlocked; and 'Nipper', a tiny phone charger that uses household batteries. The winner will be decided by a Twitter poll and funded through Kickstarter.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating £500,000 in public funds to a charity, Victims First Northumbria, of which she is a director. The charity also includes Sue Sim, Northumbria's chief constable, on its board. This has sparked criticism and accusations of a conflict of interest, with Keith Vaz, the Labour chairman of the home affairs committee, describing the situation as "inappropriate". Ms. Baird has defended her decision, stating that all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed, while Mrs. Sim has announced her upcoming retirement from the force. The Ministry of Justice has confirmed it will investigate any potential breaches of conflict of interest rules.

Three people have been sentenced to prison terms ranging from 23 months to 20 years for their involvement in a disturbing assault and torture of a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce. Corry 'Corey' Campbell, the ringleader, believed Valecce had hurt his cat and stolen from him. Campbell, along with his accomplices, subjected Valecce to 42 hours of physical and psychological abuse, including beating him, tying him to a chair, and forcibly tattooing offensive and hateful images and words on his body. The incident occurred in Philadelphia and has left Valecce with physical and mental scars, as well as a fear of going outside.
